Bug.Summery: [Workbench] [R21PRES] Support switch to Editor (CTRL + E)
Bug.WithStack:
When i switch to 2.1 presentation and if i have many editors opened (many tabs) i cannot scroll between them (i cannot access currently hidden tabs). Moreover, the menu Window->Navigation->Switch to Editor is not functional!! Also shortcut for this action (CTRL + E) is not functional.
Thanks! The missing arrow buttons for scrolling the tab area are covered by bug 78927. The tab folder supports Crtl+PageUp and Ctrl+PageDown, also Ctrl+Shift+E allows you to switch editors.
However this looks like a bug, the black arrows show up in 3.0.2 but not 3.1.
moving to SWT for comment. As Florian points out in bug 78927, the arrows are missing because in 3.1 ToolItems that are clipped are not shown. This is intentional, see Bug 15239. The sizing of the toolbar in the R21 presentation needs to be fixed.
The part about "CTRL + E" not working needs clarification and may be a completely separate bug.
I think this bug report should be marked as a duplicate of bug 78927. Moving back to UI for comment. Veronika, I don't understand. In the editor area on the R21 presentation the arrows are now gone since 3.0. Did we do something to make this happen? so the problem was that the tool items were not fully visible and now in SWT these items get hidden and so they are no longer visible. adding Ed and Gunnar, does anyone have time to look at this? It should be a simple sizing issue with the arrows on the tabs in the R2.1 presentation?
Oh and this is possibly for RC2 (i.e. this week Wednesday PM (June 8)? > does anyone have time to look at this?
Why not use bug 78927 (linked to twice in this report) as a starting point? While I'm not saying that the patch attached to that bug report is certified to be free of performance or portability issues, I'm a bit surprised by this recent flurry of trying to find out what the problem is or how to fix it when someone has already taken the time to look into this - five months ago. Bug 78927 (missing/clipped arrows) is fixed, so I'm renaming this one to just cover the Switch to Editor problem. This looks like a new feature to me. I havn't checked a Eclipse 2.1. Did it provide the the editor list?
The implementation is not trivial. IMHO the R21 presentation needs to be reworked to make use of the existing implementation (see TabbedStackPresentation#showPartList, DefaultPartList, PresentablePartFolder, etc.)
Severity should be adjusted to "enhancement" and the target milestone must be removed. I don't have the permission to do this. Updated severity, milestone, and summary to reflect comment #9. There are no plans to work on this at this time As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: [browser] context menu is never dismissed
Bug.WithStack:
3.1RC1
The Browser makes its context menu visible when it receives ContextMenuListener.OnShowContextMenu. If possible this should be changed on motif to show on right MouseDown instead. If the context menu is coming from Mozilla, then there's not much we can do. On revisiting this, the pop-up behaviour is fine on motif after all.
However, the problem I now see is that once a custom pop-up is shown then clicking elsewhere in the Browser does not dismiss it. This is probably a result of mouse events currently not being fired by the Browser. To see this problem right-click in the Javadoc view.
Moving report to triage, see http://www.eclipse.org/swt/triage.php for more info about swt bug handling.
Bug.WithOutStack:
3.1RC1
The Browser makes its context menu visible when it receives ContextMenuListener.OnShowContextMenu. If possible this should be changed on motif to show on right MouseDown instead. If the context menu is coming from Mozilla, then there's not much we can do. On revisiting this, the pop-up behaviour is fine on motif after all.
However, the problem I now see is that once a custom pop-up is shown then clicking elsewhere in the Browser does not dismiss it. This is probably a result of mouse events currently not being fired by the Browser. To see this problem right-click in the Javadoc view.
Moving report to triage, see http://www.eclipse.org/swt/triage.php for more info about swt bug handling.

Bug.Summery: Celleditor not aligned with figure once scrolled off-screen
Bug.WithStack:
If you bring up a text celleditor for direct-editing, and then scroll the diagram in such a way that the celleditor would get hidden, the celleditor is misaligned -- it is not over the figure it is editing -- once you scroll back to it. The problem is caused because SWT does not scroll the celleditor once it is not visible.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 41111 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
If you bring up a text celleditor for direct-editing, and then scroll the diagram in such a way that the celleditor would get hidden, the celleditor is misaligned -- it is not over the figure it is editing -- once you scroll back to it. The problem is caused because SWT does not scroll the celleditor once it is not visible.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 41111 ***

Lines.Line: - Switch to workingset mode
- Create several working sets
- Rearrange them
- Switch to project mode
- Close package explorer
- Reopen package explorer
- Switch to workingset mode

Bug.WithStack:
I20050527-0010
Steps to reproduce: - Switch to workingset mode - Create several working sets - Rearrange them - Switch to project mode - Close package explorer - Reopen package explorer - Switch to workingset mode
-> The working set dialog lost the order of the workingsets -> The order should be persisted either in the specialized Java workingset dialog or in the package explorer itself Not critical for 3.1 Not critical, but rather annoying. It also forgets the enablement of the working sets -> much work to get back to the original state. fixed > 20070424

Bug.Summery: o.e.h.probekit has build errors on an M7 workspace
Bug.WithStack:
I get this build error when I try to rebuild the probekit plugin ( in Java Perspective select Project > Clean.. selected project ):
Errors during build. Errors running builder "JET Builder" on project org.eclipse.hyades.probekit. Resource /org.eclipse.hyades.probekit/templates does not exist.
In the .project file, the plugin nature is defined to be <nature>org.eclipse.emf.codegen.jet.IJETNature</nature>
and it has a buildCommand for this nature
<buildCommand> <name>org.eclipse.emf.codegen.JETBuilder</name> <arguments> </arguments> </buildCommand>
If I take off this build command ( and nature )then the plugin builds okay Fixed in TPTP 4.0 i4. closing defect; verified fix
Bug.WithOutStack:

Errors during build. Errors running builder "JET Builder" on project org.eclipse.hyades.probekit. Resource /org.eclipse.hyades.probekit/templates does not exist.
In the .project file, the plugin nature is defined to be <nature>org.eclipse.emf.codegen.jet.IJETNature</nature>
and it has a buildCommand for this nature

If I take off this build command ( and nature )then the plugin builds okay Fixed in TPTP 4.0 i4. closing defect; verified fix

Bug.Summery: Validation messages showing up twice
Bug.WithStack:
All validation messages are showing up twice in the problems views. Looks to be an issue in the framework where 2 files with the same uri are being passed to the validators and hence 2 same errors messages put out by the validator. This problem is due to that fact that 2 files with the same name but in different locations are being captured by the build delta and passed to the validation builder for validation and hence 2 errors are being put out
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 97756 *** duplicate of 97756 - Once the .deployable folder is removed this defect will be fixed Changed Version field given new release numbering.

Bug.Summery: [Forms] Clipped link from Type Access Rules dialog

Lines.Line: 1) Create a new Java project
2) Go to Properties > Java Build Path > Libraries
3) Add any library to the build path.
4) Expand the library, highlight "Access rules", hit "Edit..."
5) And see this clipped link.

Bug.WithStack:
Against I20050527-0010. I'm attaching a screen shot from the Type Access Rules dialog. Clipping goes away when the link is moused-over. Created attachment 21886 The clipped link Martin, don't know if this is use for SWT. using ui.forms Some layout fixes with the FormText went into the last night nightly build. I tried to reproduce this in a small test case but could not. Can you give it a try again with N20050607 or higher (BTW, I tried the dialog in question but the link has been removed, so I had to build a simple test case). Lowering priority since it is not critical and I cannot reproduce it. Created attachment 23414 The clipped link with Windows XP look and feel
Here is the clipped link again, in N20050616-0010. To reproduce, I simply:
1) Create a new Java project 2) Go to Properties > Java Build Path > Libraries 3) Add any library to the build path. 4) Expand the library, highlight "Access rules", hit "Edit..." 5) And see this clipped link.
When I mouse over, the clipping stops, but the single quotes disappear. (screenshot to come) Created attachment 23415 Clipping and quotes disappear on mouse-over
After mouse over. The clipping is gone, and so are the quotes. This is related to a bug in focus indication rendering. The link segment used to return true from 'isSelectable()' which gave it one pixel margin around the text for drawing focus indication. During refactoring, a new method 'isFocusSelectable()' was added to IFocusSelectable interface, and this method was left orphaned. As a result, HyperlinkSegment and ImageHyperlinkSegment always returned 'true', so focus rendering was drawing on top of text. Depending on the paint ordering, you could see one segment drawing over another, or focus rectangle partially cancelling itself (due to XOR painting mode) etc.
The attached patch finally fixes all the focus rendering issues. I tested it on Windows extensively (including PDE editors, Help view, Forms examples etc.). Needless to say, it also fixes the original problem of this bug.
I will propose this bug as the only bug to be fixed in RC4 for Eclipse Forms. Added Konrad and Wassim because they are the beneficiaries of the fix (links will render better in PDE editors and the Help view). Created attachment 23495 UI Forms patch that fixes focus and link rendering Raising priority to P2. This is not a stop-ship, but detracts from the 'finished product' feel. Eclipse Forms patches that involve additions and substractions of pixels really make me nervous.
This particular patch is too large/elaborate for my RC4 tolerance level.
I think links currently look fine in the PDE editors. I'm not sure this is critical for 3.1 unless you can prove to me otherwise with a live example. I don't think pixels have any particular risk level that makes them more scary than, say, file management. It is more likely that pixel manipulation skills are not common and the provided patch seems scary as a result. If you apply the patch, you will notice that most of it consists of manipulating 1 pixel of offset and 2 pixels of total width. This compensation is done for 'selectable' text segments to make room for the focus rectangle that is rendered around these segments.
This problem was in the code for a while and I was always unhappy about it but it was never a major issue because the misalignment was only one pixel. However, I do think that now that I have a solid fix in hand, it would be a shame to go into 3.1 with a less finished product because we are scared. All PDE editors work well with the fix applied, Help view works well, the original problem of this defect is gone, and Eclipse Forms examples also work well.
I am happy to demonstrate the problem and the fix tomorrow. I also encourage you to check out Eclipse Forms, apply the patch, and go through all PDE editors to verify that no cheeze happens in sections that use FormText. what I do notice is that with the patch, I no longer have to click on a link that spans > 1 line 10-20 times to get it to work anymore, which is nice. scratch that. I now have to click on a link twice to get it work. An improvement, but still not quite there yet.
However, I am not sure this patch is supposed to address this anyway. Created attachment 23520 screenshot with patch
Observe what still occurs with the patch when I make the text in the Exporting section wrap.
The underline starts on the second to last line, while the underlined text is fully contained on the last line. This is long lasting issue. I am using Java's BreakIterator and it gives me one blank space as a valid segment before the wrap. This is nothing to do with the patch.
Please open a separate defect for the lazy link problem (again, not related to the 1-pixel offset). It did not seem like an urgent problem to me at first, but after demonstration of the exact issues addressed by Dejan's fix and reviewing the patch, I believe it is worth releasing into RC4. We can't live without a fix. +1 for RC4 Released.

Against I20050527-0010. I'm attaching a screen shot from the Type Access Rules dialog. Clipping goes away when the link is moused-over. Created attachment 21886 The clipped link Martin, don't know if this is use for SWT. using ui.forms Some layout fixes with the FormText went into the last night nightly build. Bug.Summery: Fragment project doesn't get plugin dependancies from referenced Plugin

Lines.Line: 1) unzip the attached zip file
2) create a new workspace
3) import the 2 projects (I used "Import->Existing project into workspace")
4) switch to the PDE perspective
5) in the "Package explorer" expand the "TestFrag" project (fragment)
6) the "Plug-in Dependancies" node is empty
7) the "Plug-in Dependancies" node of the "TestPlugin" is populated
8) if you edit the plugin.xml of TestPlugin and remove the version/match rule
and save the fragment will be fixed (shows dependancies)
1. We cannot tell the JDT builder to skip a project. They alone make that
decision on what needs to be skipped. so unresolved bundles with no classpath
will result in empty classpath and a million errors each.
2. A bundle can be inadvertently unresolved very easily, eg. a typo in the
Require-Bundle header. The PDE manifest builder marks that with a red x on
the manifest. However, if were to exercise tough love, then the whole plugin
will have no classpath, which is too harsh for development time.
3. As you know, a bundle can be unresolved for many reasons, including for
example, two singleton bundles by the same id in the same workspace. PDE is
working toward supporting such a scenario, but giving all unresolved bundles
an empty classpath will be a huge step backward wrt usability.

Bug.WithStack:
Problem found in R31M7, same testcase works in R302
I didn't see any open bugs for this problem.
I created a brand new fragement project (not using osgi style) and referenced a Host Plug-in in my workspace.
The java build path shows the "Plug-in dependancies" as empty, it should have listed the plugins from the Host Plug-in.
I checked using properites of the fragment project->Java Build Path->Libraries tab. It only had "Access rules(no restrictions)"
I tried this on 3.0.2 and it worked correctly, the "Plug-in dependancies" in the fragment project contained the plugins from the Host Plug-in.
The end result of this is that all the imports fail because they can't see any of the plugins rendering the fragment useless. New workspace: It works if I create a new plugin project (3.0 + no osgi) Then create a fragment project with the above plugin as the host.
Seems that PDE in 3.1 does not like the plugin.xml format that works under 3.0.2
I am trying to figure out what it is about my plugin (3.0 compatible) that causes the fragment project in R3.1 to not see the plugin-dependancies
What I am saying is that seems to be a problem with the format of my plugin.xml that works on 3.0.2 but doesn't on 3.1
Did more testing...
The problem is with the "import plugin" version/match statements in the Host plug-in's plugin.xml
The <import plugin.../> statement in the host plugin was not satisfied. i.e. it required a version that wasn't available. The host plugin found the dependancies (even though they were not satisfied) and compiled ok but the fragment apparently does more checking and failed to find the dependances.
The problem is not with the fragment but with the check on the plugin.xml import statements. It would appear that the version/match rule is not checked for plugins but is for fragments
There is an inconsistency between how a plugin checks the version/match rule on the import statement and how a fragment checks it.
If plugins don't check the version/match then the fragment shouldn't check the host plugin's import statements either.
I wrongly assumed that plugins were checking the version/match rule!
Sorry for all the appends but due to the reduced time left I want to make sure I capture everything I find on this.
it's the runtime state that determines if a fragment is resolved or unresolved. If it is unresolved, it loses connectivity with its host plugin at development time as it should.
Moving to Platform/Runtime to ensure that the fragment is correctly unresolved. I suspect this is a user error. It would help if you provided a plugin.xml/fragment.xml for both the host and fragment plugins which are causing you problems. I'm having a hard time figuring out what your scenario is. Does you fragment have any <import plugin.../> statements? Does it import additional plugins that the host does not? Does it import the same plugins as the host but at a different version?
In the runtime State, if a host bundle is not resolved then a fragment bundle is not allowed to resolve to the host bundle. This may be the behavior you are seeing, but it is hard to guess without examples of the plugin.xml/fragment.xml files.
Created attachment 21911 Contains the plugin and fragment Attaching testcase to reproduce the problem:
1) unzip the attached zip file 2) create a new workspace 3) import the 2 projects (I used "Import->Existing project into workspace") 4) switch to the PDE perspective 5) in the "Package explorer" expand the "TestFrag" project (fragment) 6) the "Plug-in Dependancies" node is empty 7) the "Plug-in Dependancies" node of the "TestPlugin" is populated
8) if you edit the plugin.xml of TestPlugin and remove the version/match rule and save the fragment will be fixed (shows dependancies)
It was very misleading that the dependancies in the plugin worked but the fragment failed because it tested the version/match rule. seems like a PDE issue. May be something ultimately at the state level but lets start with PDE UI. Here it is:
The reason why everything worked fine in 3.0.2 is because PDE back then did not use the runtime state to determine dependencies, so it was too lenient when it comes to unresolved dependencies.
In this case, the plugin is unresolved because of the unsatisfied dependency. The fragment therefore now has no host and we ask the runtime for what is visible for the fragment, the list is empty and hence the empty container.
As for the plugin, even though it is unresolved, PDE still tries to construct a classpath for it by navigating its list of dependencies as specified in the manifest. So we are still consciously more lenient than the runtime when it comes to plugins. If we weren't, then your project would have thousands of compiler errors.
This is a judgment call on the part of PDE for more plesant workflows. What's the deal here? do people want PDE to be as strict as the state and give the plugin an empty classpath too?
Jeff? (sorry for moving it back to PDE in comment 8. Wasn't paying attention to what was going on...)
Strictly from a class visibility point of view, if a plugin is not resolved, I would say that it just should not compile. That is, it should not build. There should be a red X on the project with suggestive text in the error message.
I don't know what it would mean for PDE to guess at the classpath. It might get it right but in the end all that is happening is a reduction in the error count.
Having said that, I have not considered the usecases. For all I know I have been the ignorant beneficiary of PDE's benevolence and would simply fall on the floor crying if the function went away. I'm doubting most of that but its worth consideration.
Wassim, can you outline some workflows that are more pleasant because of your handiwork in this area?
Two main issues: 1. We cannot tell the JDT builder to skip a project. They alone make that decision on what needs to be skipped. so unresolved bundles with no classpath will result in empty classpath and a million errors each.
2. A bundle can be inadvertently unresolved very easily, eg. a typo in the Require-Bundle header. The PDE manifest builder marks that with a red x on the manifest. However, if were to exercise tough love, then the whole plugin will have no classpath, which is too harsh for development time.
3. As you know, a bundle can be unresolved for many reasons, including for example, two singleton bundles by the same id in the same workspace. PDE is working toward supporting such a scenario, but giving all unresolved bundles an empty classpath will be a huge step backward wrt usability.
That is why PDE is consciously lenient when it comes to plugins.
For fragments, PDE can't be as lenient of course, since the call to getHost() will return null by the state and we therefore leave it at that.
Therefore, I think the current behavior has the right mix of tough love without the millions of compiler errors at development time. I think what we need to do here is if the version constraint is not met as error, then the manifest builder should flag it too. And we leave the classpath computation as-is. sounds good?
This will apply to manifested plugins only of course. We will not invest in old-style plugins. ok. that sounds fine for 3.1
Some observations: - 1 and 2 are basically you working around the inabilty to tell JDT that a project's classpath is invalid (btw, could you stick a bogus dependency there that is not met? I get "cant' build X because prereq Y is not defined" all the time)
- #3 is interesting. What would be cool is if the resolver resolved as much as it could and did as many bindings as it can in all cases. Then PDE could simply check to see if all the prereqs were met. If they are, the project can compile. If not, it can't. Something for a future date... I think you rather get "cant' build X because prereq Y CANNOT be built. A full rebuild is required". If you only have plugin projects, then you should never get into that state. However, bug 96575 is one example of why this might happen.
Konrad, please add the following checks to the manifest builder:
1. If a plugin is unresolved due a unsatisfied version constraint, flag it at the same level as unresolved dependencies.
2. If a fragment has an unresolved host, flag it at the same level as unresolved dependencies. (In reply to comment #12) > I think what we need to do here is if the version constraint is not met as > error, then the manifest builder should flag it too. And we leave the > classpath computation as-is. sounds good? > This will apply to manifested plugins only of course. We will not invest in > old-style plugins.
I like the idea of at least getting a warning. I didn't know I had a problem until I started working on the fragment and even then I had a hard time understanding why it wasn't finding the host plugins dependancies. As it is I make sure that my environment is targeting the correct platform so I wouldn't mind if the plugin just didn't build. Don't generate lots of errors just tell me that one of the dependancies didn't match if that is possible. >I like the idea of at least getting a warning.
and that you will get. We already do the checks described in comment #15, but for plugins/fragments with manifest.mf. plugin.xml and fragment.xml have never performed the check and we dont have to improve on these at 3.1. (In reply to comment #18) > We already do the checks described in comment #15, but for plugins/fragments > with manifest.mf. plugin.xml and fragment.xml have never performed the check > and we dont have to improve on these at 3.1.
I don't think it is reasonable to rely on everyone moving up to the latest format to solve an existing problem. This is more of an enhancement (ie. extra/better validation messages).
There are a lot of enhancements that can be taken advantage of with the new formats which are not there for old-style plugins. It would be a waste of time/effort to backport all these enhancements to the old plugin style format that is effectively deprecated as of 3.1.
Konrad, please resolve as appropriate. With respect to plugin.xml/fragment.xml I mark this as Wontfix.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Problem found in R31M7, same testcase works in R302
I didn't see any open bugs for this problem.
I created a brand new fragement project (not using osgi style) and referenced a Host Plug-in in my workspace.
The java build path shows the "Plug-in dependancies" as empty, it should have listed the plugins from the Host Plug-in.
I checked using properites of the fragment project->Java Build Path->Libraries tab. It only had "Access rules(no restrictions)"
I tried this on 3.0.2 and it worked correctly, the "Plug-in dependancies" in the fragment project contained the plugins from the Host Plug-in.
The end result of this is that all the imports fail because they can't see any of the plugins rendering the fragment useless. New workspace: It works if I create a new plugin project (3.0 + no osgi) Then create a fragment project with the above plugin as the host.
Seems that PDE in 3.1 does not like the plugin.xml format that works under 3.0.2
I am trying to figure out what it is about my plugin (3.0 compatible) that causes the fragment project in R3.1 to not see the plugin-dependancies
What I am saying is that seems to be a problem with the format of my plugin.xml that works on 3.0.2 but doesn't on 3.1
Did more testing...
The problem is with the "import plugin" version/match statements in the Host plug-in's plugin.xml
The <import plugin.../> statement in the host plugin was not satisfied. i.e. it required a version that wasn't available. The host plugin found the dependancies (even though they were not satisfied) and compiled ok but the fragment apparently does more checking and failed to find the dependances.
The problem is not with the fragment but with the check on the plugin.xml import statements. It would appear that the version/match rule is not checked for plugins but is for fragments
There is an inconsistency between how a plugin checks the version/match rule on the import statement and how a fragment checks it.
If plugins don't check the version/match then the fragment shouldn't check the host plugin's import statements either.
I wrongly assumed that plugins were checking the version/match rule!
Sorry for all the appends but due to the reduced time left I want to make sure I capture everything I find on this.
it's the runtime state that determines if a fragment is resolved or unresolved. If it is unresolved, it loses connectivity with its host plugin at development time as it should.
Moving to Platform/Runtime to ensure that the fragment is correctly unresolved. I suspect this is a user error. It would help if you provided a plugin.xml/fragment.xml for both the host and fragment plugins which are causing you problems. I'm having a hard time figuring out what your scenario is. Does you fragment have any <import plugin.../> statements? Does it import additional plugins that the host does not? Does it import the same plugins as the host but at a different version?
In the runtime State, if a host bundle is not resolved then a fragment bundle is not allowed to resolve to the host bundle. This may be the behavior you are seeing, but it is hard to guess without examples of the plugin.xml/fragment.xml files.
Created attachment 21911 Contains the plugin and fragment Attaching testcase to reproduce the problem:
1) unzip the attached zip file 2) create a new workspace 3) import the 2 projects (I used "Import->Existing project into workspace") 4) switch to the PDE perspective 5) in the "Package explorer" expand the "TestFrag" project (fragment) 6) the "Plug-in Dependancies" node is empty 7) the "Plug-in Dependancies" node of the "TestPlugin" is populated
8) if you edit the plugin.xml of TestPlugin and remove the version/match rule and save the fragment will be fixed (shows dependancies)
It was very misleading that the dependancies in the plugin worked but the fragment failed because it tested the version/match rule. seems like a PDE issue. May be something ultimately at the state level but lets start with PDE UI. Here it is:
The reason why everything worked fine in 3.0.2 is because PDE back then did not use the runtime state to determine dependencies, so it was too lenient when it comes to unresolved dependencies.
In this case, the plugin is unresolved because of the unsatisfied dependency. The fragment therefore now has no host and we ask the runtime for what is visible for the fragment, the list is empty and hence the empty container.
As for the plugin, even though it is unresolved, PDE still tries to construct a classpath for it by navigating its list of dependencies as specified in the manifest. So we are still consciously more lenient than the runtime when it comes to plugins. If we weren't, then your project would have thousands of compiler errors.
This is a judgment call on the part of PDE for more plesant workflows. What's the deal here? do people want PDE to be as strict as the state and give the plugin an empty classpath too?
Jeff? (sorry for moving it back to PDE in comment 8. Wasn't paying attention to what was going on...)
Strictly from a class visibility point of view, if a plugin is not resolved, I would say that it just should not compile. That is, it should not build. There should be a red X on the project with suggestive text in the error message.
I don't know what it would mean for PDE to guess at the classpath. It might get it right but in the end all that is happening is a reduction in the error count.
Having said that, I have not considered the usecases. For all I know I have been the ignorant beneficiary of PDE's benevolence and would simply fall on the floor crying if the function went away. I'm doubting most of that but its worth consideration.
Wassim, can you outline some workflows that are more pleasant because of your handiwork in this area?
Two main issues: 1. We cannot tell the JDT builder to skip a project. They alone make that decision on what needs to be skipped. so unresolved bundles with no classpath will result in empty classpath and a million errors each.
2. A bundle can be inadvertently unresolved very easily, eg. a typo in the Require-Bundle header. The PDE manifest builder marks that with a red x on the manifest. However, if were to exercise tough love, then the whole plugin will have no classpath, which is too harsh for development time.
3. As you know, a bundle can be unresolved for many reasons, including for example, two singleton bundles by the same id in the same workspace. PDE is working toward supporting such a scenario, but giving all unresolved bundles an empty classpath will be a huge step backward wrt usability.
That is why PDE is consciously lenient when it comes to plugins.
For fragments, PDE can't be as lenient of course, since the call to getHost() will return null by the state and we therefore leave it at that.
Therefore, I think the current behavior has the right mix of tough love without the millions of compiler errors at development time. I think what we need to do here is if the version constraint is not met as error, then the manifest builder should flag it too. And we leave the classpath computation as-is. sounds good?
This will apply to manifested plugins only of course. We will not invest in old-style plugins. ok. that sounds fine for 3.1
Some observations: - 1 and 2 are basically you working around the inabilty to tell JDT that a project's classpath is invalid (btw, could you stick a bogus dependency there that is not met? I get "cant' build X because prereq Y is not defined" all the time)
- #3 is interesting. What would be cool is if the resolver resolved as much as it could and did as many bindings as it can in all cases. Then PDE could simply check to see if all the prereqs were met. If they are, the project can compile. If not, it can't. Something for a future date... I think you rather get "cant' build X because prereq Y CANNOT be built. A full rebuild is required". If you only have plugin projects, then you should never get into that state. However, bug 96575 is one example of why this might happen.
Konrad, please add the following checks to the manifest builder:
1. If a plugin is unresolved due a unsatisfied version constraint, flag it at the same level as unresolved dependencies.
2. If a fragment has an unresolved host, flag it at the same level as unresolved dependencies. (In reply to comment #12) > I think what we need to do here is if the version constraint is not met as > error, then the manifest builder should flag it too. And we leave the > classpath computation as-is. sounds good? > This will apply to manifested plugins only of course. We will not invest in > old-style plugins.
I like the idea of at least getting a warning. I didn't know I had a problem until I started working on the fragment and even then I had a hard time understanding why it wasn't finding the host plugins dependancies. As it is I make sure that my environment is targeting the correct platform so I wouldn't mind if the plugin just didn't build. Don't generate lots of errors just tell me that one of the dependancies didn't match if that is possible. >I like the idea of at least getting a warning.
and that you will get. We already do the checks described in comment #15, but for plugins/fragments with manifest.mf. plugin.xml and fragment.xml have never performed the check and we dont have to improve on these at 3.1. (In reply to comment #18) > We already do the checks described in comment #15, but for plugins/fragments > with manifest.mf. plugin.xml and fragment.xml have never performed the check > and we dont have to improve on these at 3.1.
I don't think it is reasonable to rely on everyone moving up to the latest format to solve an existing problem. This is more of an enhancement (ie. extra/better validation messages).
There are a lot of enhancements that can be taken advantage of with the new formats which are not there for old-style plugins. It would be a waste of time/effort to backport all these enhancements to the old plugin style format that is effectively deprecated as of 3.1.

Bug.Summery: Custom Table font is not applied to first column header

Lines.Line: 1. Create a custom Font.
2. Create a Table.
3. Make the Table's header visible and set its font to the custom font.
4. Add multiple columns to the Table.
Actual results: The first column in the header uses the default system font,
and all the others use the custom font.
Expected results: All columns in the header use the custom font.
I'm using SWT/GTK 3.1M7. I think this is platform-specific, since I don't
remember this bug occurring in Windows; but I'll have to check to make sure.
What version of GTK+ are you using?
I'm using 2.4.9 at work (SuSE 9.2) and 2.4.14 at home (Fedora Core 3). The bug
occurs on both.
I'm seeing a similar problem, but it's not quite what you described so I'd like
to confirm. Basically, table.setFont() on SWT/GTK+ currently only applies to
columns already created. Columns created after the call to table.setFont() get
the system default font. I am confused because your bug says the opposite.

Bug.Summery: subpackages lose their names in genmodels

Lines.Line: - ecore and genmodel before adding the 2nd package
- ecore and genmodel after adding the 2nd package
Created attachment 21897
requested sample files
When you change the ecore model that is referred by a genmodel (in other words,
the ecore located in the same directory of the genmodel), you don't need to
reload the genmodel (the changes are reconciled automatically when you open the
GenModel editor) **and** you are supposed to do some extra changes, such as
setting the prefix attribute of the genPackage created for your new EPackage.

Bug.WithStack:
Create an ecore resource with a package P1. Create a genmodel from the ecore file. Edit the ecore file by creating a subpackage P2 under P1. Reload the genmodel. Open the genmodel. P2 loses its name and causes EMF to assign the generated package the "Package" name. Thx for reporting the problem.
Can you please attach here the files? Maybe you could attach one zip file for each line below - ecore and genmodel before adding the 2nd package - ecore and genmodel after adding the 2nd package Created attachment 21897 requested sample files When you change the ecore model that is referred by a genmodel (in other words, the ecore located in the same directory of the genmodel), you don't need to reload the genmodel (the changes are reconciled automatically when you open the GenModel editor) **and** you are supposed to do some extra changes, such as setting the prefix attribute of the genPackage created for your new EPackage.
This is different than, for example, creating a genmodel for a given ecore and saving the genmodel file in a different directory. Actually, if you look closely, you will notice that a copy of the ecore file is created in the genmodel's directory.
That said, the problem you are seeing is happening because the new GenPackage doesn't have a 'Prefix' (you can set it through the GenModel editor). To make the tree look a little nicer, I've changed the genPackage content provider to present the name of the EPackage between '[' and ']' when genPackage.getPrefix() returns null or an empty string. I am currently using a tool I wrote that generates the ecore files from uml2 models. Is there a way I can specify the package prefix and the basePackage in the ecore file so it would be picked by the genmodel. Having to type that information every time a regenerate the ecore is very error prone. May be somekind of annotation I can attach to the EPackage that specifies the prefix and the basePackage? We don't have anything that would do that for you.
That said, maybe your tool could reconcile the ecore and gen models (look at the GenModelEditor.initialize(GenModel) method) and then adjust the genPackages setting their prefixes (which are usually the 'non qualified' name of the ePackage, uppercasing the first letter) and basePackages. Thnx for the info. I didn't know I didn't have to reload the genmodel. But that solves my problem. At least I have to enter the info only once in the genmodel. You can close the bugzilla if you want to. I glad it solved your problem. We will be closing this defect when we publish our next build. Fixed in build 2.1.0.I200506020944. Move to verified as per bug 206558.

Bug.Summery: PDE generates to strict access restrictions

Lines.Line: - download EMF using the update manager (don't know if this is necessary)
- observe: the install plug-in has a manifest file which only contains one
line:
Manifest-Version: 1.0
- it also contains a plugin.xml file which exports the following entries:
<runtime>
<library name="runtime/ecore.jar">
<export name="*"/>
<packages prefixes="org.eclipse.emf.ecore"/>
</library>
</runtime>

Bug.WithStack:
I20050527-0010
- download EMF using the update manager (don't know if this is necessary) - observe: the install plug-in has a manifest file which only contains one line: Manifest-Version: 1.0 - it also contains a plugin.xml file which exports the following entries: <runtime> <library name="runtime/ecore.jar"> <export name="*"/> <packages prefixes="org.eclipse.emf.ecore"/> </library> </runtime>
This result in the following access restriction for clients using emf.core ==> **/* forbidden reference
As a result all usages to emf core classes even those in API package are flagged as an error.
Since having a one liner manifest file seems to be a legal setup PDE should honor the access restrictions from the plugin.xml file and not generate a ALL forbidden rule only. Fixed.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20050527-0010
- download EMF using the update manager (don't know if this is necessary) - observe: the install plug-in has a manifest file which only contains one line: Manifest-Version: 1.0 - it also contains a plugin.xml file which exports the following entries: <runtime> <library name="runtime/ecore.jar"> <export name="*"/> <packages prefixes="org.eclipse.emf.ecore"/> </library> </runtime>
This result in the following access restriction for clients using emf.core ==> **/* forbidden reference
As a result all usages to emf core classes even those in API package are flagged as an error.
Since having a one liner manifest file seems to be a legal setup PDE should honor the access restrictions from the plugin.xml file and not generate a ALL forbidden rule only. Fixed.

Bug.Summery: Implicit C Types should use new CBasicType constructor

source_code.code: - changed types to refer to each other ie cpp_void_p = new CPPPointer( cpp_void );

Lines.Line: - long is semantically the same as long int, removed the duplicate.
- bits fields are combined with | not & (ie CBasicType.IS_LONG |
CBasicType.IS_UNSIGNED)

Bug.WithStack:
CBasicType now has a CBasicType( int type, int qualifiers ) constructors (like the CPPBasicType has).
This means GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider doesn't need to create ICASTSimpleDeclSpecifier objects anymore, it can create the basic types directly. The types in GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider should also be created only once. I had a patch for this but lost it somewhere in the madness when John was gone for a couple of days. I'll redo this as part of a fix for this PR. Patch sent to cdt-patch@eclipse.org Created attachment 21992 patch for PR 92020
GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider now creates basic types directly, and only once. This means that GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider is much cleaner than it was before and as such is much easier to maintain. Andrew can you look at/apply this patch? patch applied with modifications: - changed type fields to static final and used a static initializer - changed types to refer to each other ie cpp_void_p = new CPPPointer( cpp_void ); - long is semantically the same as long int, removed the duplicate. - bits fields are combined with | not & (ie CBasicType.IS_LONG | CBasicType.IS_UNSIGNED)
Bug.WithOutStack:
CBasicType now has a CBasicType( int type, int qualifiers ) constructors (like the CPPBasicType has).
This means GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider doesn't need to create ICASTSimpleDeclSpecifier objects anymore, it can create the basic types directly. The types in GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider should also be created only once. I had a patch for this but lost it somewhere in the madness when John was gone for a couple of days. I'll redo this as part of a fix for this PR. Patch sent to cdt-patch@eclipse.org Created attachment 21992 patch for PR 92020
GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider now creates basic types directly, and only once. This means that GCCBuiltinSymbolProvider is much cleaner than it was before and as such is much easier to maintain. Andrew can you look at/apply this patch? patch applied with modifications: - changed type fields to static final and used a static initializer - changed types to refer to each other ie cpp_void_p = new CPPPointer( cpp_void ); - long is semantically the same as long int, removed the duplicate. - bits fields are combined with | not & (ie CBasicType.IS_LONG | CBasicType.IS_UNSIGNED)

Bug.Summery: [About] [Graphics] About dialog on Mac has space under the image
Bug.WithStack:
Due to the size of the text, removing the borders around the image has caused a white space to appear under the image.
build N20050525 kim, is this still happening on 3.2? It looks fine to me. thanks kim Created attachment 28895 arrow showing space below About graphic
If possible would like About graphic to be flush to bottom border. Height of text area to right of graphic determines height of area where graphic is placed. Not sure if this is the cause here, but can you see if it can be adjusted to remove the 1 pl. space shown in attachment? Thanks Kim. I think this is supposed to be 3.2 M3. nah, I didn't fix it just found that it appeared to be fixed. Actually turns out in comment #4 that it does not appear fixed, reopening to get rid of the line of text below the image on Mac I think I figured this one out.
There is a horizontal separator under the image that is two pixels high. On the mac the first pixel is white the second is dark. On Windows it is the other way around.
This gives the appearance of an extra white pixel under the image because the text background on the right is also white so this blends in.
closing

Bug.Summery: NPE in log after shutdown
Bug.WithStack:
The following was logged while shuting down (I believe the buidl was I20050526 but it may have been an early nightly as well).
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.DataArea.getLogLocation(DataArea.java:64) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.getLogFileLocation(Platform.java:634) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.runtime.logview.LogView.logging(LogView.java:565) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform$2.run (InternalPlatform.java:850) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.run (InternalPlatform.java:1038) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.log (InternalPlatform.java:853) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.log(Worker.java:48) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:85) InternalPlatform.frameworkLog is set to null on shutdown. This is another case where behaviour of Platform API methods is undefined after runtime has shut down. If it's not possible to compute the log location after shutdown, I guess we should throw IllegalStateException() to avoid the NPE. John suggested that "Worker.run should check if the platform is shutdown and not try to log". Fine polish item. CCing DJ for RC2 fix approval. +1 for RC2. Fix released.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The following was logged while shuting down (I believe the buidl was I20050526 but it may have been an early nightly as well).
InternalPlatform.frameworkLog is set to null on shutdown. This is another case where behaviour of Platform API methods is undefined after runtime has shut down. If it's not possible to compute the log location after shutdown, I guess we should throw IllegalStateException() to avoid the NPE. John suggested that "Worker.run should check if the platform is shutdown and not try to log". Fine polish item. CCing DJ for RC2 fix approval. +1 for RC2. Fix released.

Bug.Summery: [override marker] Incorrect override method marker
Bug.WithStack:
In this case BB.test does not override AA.test, but its tagged in the editor that it does.
class AA<T> { public AA<Object> test() { return null; } } class BB extends AA<CC> { public <T> BB test() { return null; } } class CC {} The editor uses the info provided by the bindings. But moving to text to make sure. I'm using the helper methods from JDT UI. Same problem with override decorator. Martin, can you please have a look and move on the JDT/Core if we simply call the methods on core. we're still using our homebrewed 'override' check. Markus, what are the latest news on 'MethodBinding.overrides()' ? No news lately. Methods IMethodBinding#overrides(..) and #isSubsignature(..) are currently not used because they don't work across binding environments. However, they're implemented and should work for bindings from one compiler loop, but they have not been tested "in the field". We should try to switch and use the jdt.core infrastructure here. fixed > 20050606 I've reverted the change in Bindings.findOverriddenMethodInType(..), since it cause 4 failing TypeMismatchQuickFixTests. The old implementation did not check return types, but IMethodBinding#overrides(..) does. not for 3.1. IMethodBinding.override is not yet used, its too late to start testing this now. Martin, we should investigate whether this can be fixed for 3.1.1. A similar bug is 100233. We should either switch to the core method here (which results in some fuzzyness we had regarding the return type) or add this case to the Bindings implementation we have right now. Martin, Markus can you please coordinate the fix for 97927 & 100233. IMO they will affect the same method(s) in class Bindings. I suggest we do the fix as suggested in bug 100233. IMO, changing to IMethodBinding.override for 3.1.1 is not an option. Martin, I opt to mark this one as a dup of 100233 if we agree on fixing 100233 for 3.1.1.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 100233 ***

Bug.Summery: [DetachedViews] Stacked detached views doesn't honour workspace tab settings

Lines.Line: - set the workspace preferences to use rounded tabs
- set the prefs to put the tabs on the top
- detach 2 views and stack them
- note that the tabs are square and on the bottom of the view

Bug.WithStack:
build i0527-0900
- set the workspace preferences to use rounded tabs - set the prefs to put the tabs on the top - detach 2 views and stack them - note that the tabs are square and on the bottom of the view
I would expect detached stacked views to inherit the workspace settings of rounded tabs on the top of the view. Tried that. With the OS trim enabled, you end up seeing the title of the view twice (once in the window title and once in the tab), which looks goofy when you only have one tab. Might not be so bad if we continue to hide the tabs when there's only one, though.
agree, we should honour the tab style and location and when there is only one consider just not showing the tab. *** Bug 97880 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 96911 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Fixed in head by the patch to bug 97497. Verified in I20050610-0010, GTK+, by following the steps with the preferences for tabs set in different combinations.
Bug.WithOutStack:
build i0527-0900
- set the workspace preferences to use rounded tabs - set the prefs to put the tabs on the top - detach 2 views and stack them - note that the tabs are square and on the bottom of the view
I would expect detached stacked views to inherit the workspace settings of rounded tabs on the top of the view. Tried that. With the OS trim enabled, you end up seeing the title of the view twice (once in the window title and once in the tab), which looks goofy when you only have one tab. Might not be so bad if we continue to hide the tabs when there's only one, though.
agree, we should honour the tab style and location and when there is only one consider just not showing the tab. *** Bug 97880 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 96911 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Fixed in head by the patch to bug 97497. Verified in I20050610-0010, GTK+, by following the steps with the preferences for tabs set in different combinations.

Bug.Summery: [refactoring] [general issue] Undo menu entry for Extract Method is not readable [refactoring]

Lines.Line: - Create JUnit project
- Extract some portion of code from junit.swingui.AboutDialog
- Examine undo menu

Bug.WithStack:
3.1 RC1 Candidate
Steps to reproduce: - Create JUnit project - Extract some portion of code from junit.swingui.AboutDialog - Examine undo menu
-> Menu entry is never entirely readable -> "Undo Extract 'method()'" would be enough
Note also the capitalization. There are also other refactorings with the same problem Created attachment 21896 Screenshot This is like this since day one. Not ciritical for 3.1. Deferring since fixing this require new API in the commands framework. . As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
3.1 RC1 Candidate
Steps to reproduce: - Create JUnit project - Extract some portion of code from junit.swingui.AboutDialog - Examine undo menu
-> Menu entry is never entirely readable -> "Undo Extract 'method()'" would be enough
Note also the capitalization. There are also other refactorings with the same problem Created attachment 21896 Screenshot This is like this since day one. Not ciritical for 3.1. Deferring since fixing this require new API in the commands framework. . As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Regression(?): New build error in M7 that was OK earlier
Bug.WithStack:
I have a plugin project that uses EMF. At some point in its past, the JET build nature was added to it, so it appears in the .project file. But the "templates" directory and ".jetproperties" files are not checked in to CVS for my plugin.
The project just rolled forward to Eclipse M7, and now the build reports an error regarding my project:
Errors during build. Errors running builder "JET Builder" on project org.eclipse.hyades.probekit. Resource /org.eclipse.hyades.probekit/templates does not exist.
Prior to the move up to M7, there were no build errors. My plugin hasn't changed: it never had a "templates" directory, and it has had the JET nature in the .project file for a long time.
This feels like a regression. It's possible that it's just a tightening of a requirement somewhere, but as a customer of EMF who has been building successfully all this time, it feels like a regression. I hope an EMF person can respond and explain the situation, and maybe look at the possibility of making the JET builder fail gracefully as it has in the past. Allan,
After our conversation, I think it's clear that the best thing to do is to clean up your .project file so that you don't have a jet nature or jet builder that you don't want and need anyway...
Bug.WithOutStack:
I have a plugin project that uses EMF. At some point in its past, the JET build nature was added to it, so it appears in the .project file. But the "templates" directory and ".jetproperties" files are not checked in to CVS for my plugin.
The project just rolled forward to Eclipse M7, and now the build reports an error regarding my project:
Errors during build. Errors running builder "JET Builder" on project org.eclipse.hyades.probekit. Resource /org.eclipse.hyades.probekit/templates does not exist.
Prior to the move up to M7, there were no build errors. My plugin hasn't changed: it never had a "templates" directory, and it has had the JET nature in the .project file for a long time.
This feels like a regression. It's possible that it's just a tightening of a requirement somewhere, but as a customer of EMF who has been building successfully all this time, it feels like a regression. I hope an EMF person can respond and explain the situation, and maybe look at the possibility of making the JET builder fail gracefully as it has in the past. Allan,
After our conversation, I think it's clear that the best thing to do is to clean up your .project file so that you don't have a jet nature or jet builder that you don't want and need anyway...

Bug.Summery: [Import/Export] Loss of focus in text widget causes long search when typing in a directory with lots of files
Bug.WithStack:
If I open the "Import Existing Projects" wizard then type in the first few segments of the path I plan to browse, then select browse it fires off a long search.
This should not happen when browse is selected. This is a tough one because loss of focus on the text widget causes the project list to update as a convenience for the user. If there was no focus lost listener then you would have to hit the Refresh button if you were to type in a path. I suggest that if focus is lost and the receiver of the focus is the browse button then we don't refresh the list. There are no plans to work on this currently
Bug.WithOutStack:
If I open the "Import Existing Projects" wizard then type in the first few segments of the path I plan to browse, then select browse it fires off a long search.
This should not happen when browse is selected. This is a tough one because loss of focus on the text widget causes the project list to update as a convenience for the user. If there was no focus lost listener then you would have to hit the Refresh button if you were to type in a path. I suggest that if focus is lost and the receiver of the focus is the browse button then we don't refresh the list. There are no plans to work on this currently

Bug.Summery: [Workbench] Remove trim from StartupProgressMonitorDialog

Lines.Line: - removed trimmings
- remove about image
- changed text in progress message from "Loading Plugins..." to "Starting
<Product>..."
- added a hidden parent shell to ensure the dialog does not show up as a top
level shell (e.g. in windows start bar)
- deleted some unused messages

Bug.WithStack:
At the earliest convenient opportunity, we should change StartupProgressMonitorDialog to have no trim. The change is to add to the constructor: setShellStyle(SWT.TOOL); Sorry SWT.TOOL provides the thin shell trimming, not no trim. However this bug might be invalid if we try a solution where we keep the splash and float a very simple progress window on top with no trim. I said "no trim" when I meant "no title", sorry. I think the progress dialog should have a (thin) border, using SWT.NONE or SWT.TOOL. The former adds a one- pixel black border, the latter adds a one-pixel black border with shadow. Fixed the following in HEAD. - removed trimmings - remove about image - changed text in progress message from "Loading Plugins..." to "Starting <Product>..." - added a hidden parent shell to ensure the dialog does not show up as a top level shell (e.g. in windows start bar) - deleted some unused messages
- changed ChooseWorkspaceDialog to center on the monitor clientarea on startup so that the two dialogs open in a similar fashion
logged bug 98176 against SWT for centering the splash on the monitor client area Verified in I20050610-0010.
Bug.WithOutStack:
At the earliest convenient opportunity, we should change StartupProgressMonitorDialog to have no trim. The change is to add to the constructor: setShellStyle(SWT.TOOL); Sorry SWT.TOOL provides the thin shell trimming, not no trim. However this bug might be invalid if we try a solution where we keep the splash and float a very simple progress window on top with no trim. I said "no trim" when I meant "no title", sorry. I think the progress dialog should have a (thin) border, using SWT.NONE or SWT.TOOL. The former adds a one- pixel black border, the latter adds a one-pixel black border with shadow. Fixed the following in HEAD. - removed trimmings - remove about image - changed text in progress message from "Loading Plugins..." to "Starting <Product>..." - added a hidden parent shell to ensure the dialog does not show up as a top level shell (e.g. in windows start bar) - deleted some unused messages
- changed ChooseWorkspaceDialog to center on the monitor clientarea on startup so that the two dialogs open in a similar fashion
logged bug 98176 against SWT for centering the splash on the monitor client area Verified in I20050610-0010.

Bug.Summery: [jarexporter] JAR Export issues unnecessary duplicate entry messages

Lines.Line: - Create JUnit project
- Import JUnit source for archive
- Launch JAR exporter on whole project
- Choose to export all output folders for the checked projects and all Java
source files and resources
- Choose a jar file name which does not yet exist
- Press finish

Bug.WithStack:
3.1 RC1 candidate
Steps to reproduce: - Create JUnit project - Import JUnit source for archive - Launch JAR exporter on whole project - Choose to export all output folders for the checked projects and all Java source files and resources - Choose a jar file name which does not yet exist - Press finish
-> JAR exporter shows several warnings -> It seems that the two chosen options result in non-disjunct file sets, which are not properly merged before passing to the JAR writer -> In order to make the warnings useful, this case should not trigger warnings Not critical for 3.1. Deferring... As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
3.1 RC1 candidate
Steps to reproduce: - Create JUnit project - Import JUnit source for archive - Launch JAR exporter on whole project - Choose to export all output folders for the checked projects and all Java source files and resources - Choose a jar file name which does not yet exist - Press finish
-> JAR exporter shows several warnings -> It seems that the two chosen options result in non-disjunct file sets, which are not properly merged before passing to the JAR writer -> In order to make the warnings useful, this case should not trigger warnings Not critical for 3.1. Deferring... As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Shell computeTrim and size do not reflect the free single-pixel border

When I set the same image to top level shell I see a corrupt image in the top left corner of the window. The issue seems to be related to the handling of transparent and semi-transparent pixels. Bug.Summery: [JUnit] Expose public APIs for JUnitBaseLaunchRunner
Bug.WithStack: I have written a Cactus Run-On-Server function (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=90003) that uses the JUnit ILaunchConfigurationType to do the heavy lifting. In order to accurately set attributes in the launcher, I need to use the constants defined in JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration which are in an internal package. It would be nice if there was a legitimate public API for doing this so external packages could better use the JUnit launch code, either by putting those constants in a public API, or having some other public way for setting those values. API is frozen for 3.1. Deferrring... As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack: I have written a Cactus Run-On-Server function (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=90003) that uses the JUnit ILaunchConfigurationType to do the heavy lifting. In order to accurately set attributes in the launcher, I need to use the constants defined in JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration which are in an internal package. It would be nice if there was a legitimate public API for doing this so external packages could better use the JUnit launch code, either by putting those constants in a public API, or having some other public way for setting those values. API is frozen for 3.1. Deferrring... As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Best match image is not selected for shell using .ICO files
Bug.WithStack:
I am using 3.1 M7. When I set to a shell.setImages() with an array of images of different sizes and color depth, I do not see the best match selected as the window icon. It seems like the first image in the list with the appropriate resolution is selected (16*16) even though a higher color density image is later in the list and can be shown in the display. When I remove the lower color density one from the list, I see the correct one is selected. Can you attach the images please? Thanks. Created attachment 21996 Icon file with different icons of different size and depth
This sample can be used to see that not the optimal icon is taken by the shell. Note that when the lower depth images are removed, the higher depth icons display just fine Sorry, not for 3.1. You can work around the problem by using Display.getIconDepth() filter the list of icons before calling Shell.setIcons (). I noticed that the Shell was taking a bigger Icon for the Top-Left window when passing a list of Gif-Images to Shell#setImages, but when passing Png-Images only 16x16 was used.
Ben Ben, can you attach the list of images to this bug report? The bug was not fixed for .ICO files that contain alpha but should be fixed for the other file formats. The problem is that we can't detect Windows HICON's that have alpha and so don't prefer them on XP to HICON's without. Ok, I think my suggestion was wrong. I checked the size by using Photoshop and not my eyes and it turns out that both for PNG and GIF the 16x16px Image was used, which is correct. The GIF image appeard bigger to me, but it is'nt.
Ben We did fix this problem recently for everything but .ICO files. The problem is that we lose the depth and alpha information when we create HICON's. The non-ICO part of this bug was fixed for RC2 (see bug 98894).

Bug.Summery: Rose cat finder algorithm should consider the plugin version

Bug.WithOutStack: Using the runtime plugins, there is a great chance to have the cat file in a directory <pluginID>_<pluginVersion>. The code handle this case. The fix is committed to CVS. Fixed in build 2.1.0.I200506020944. Move to verified as per bug 206558.

Bug.Summery: [Widgets] Icons with semi transparent pixels not shown correct when ALT+TAB
Bug.WithStack:
I am using 3.1 M7. I added to a shell images using setImages(). The images were created from different sized icons with semi-transparent pixels in them. The icon on the window itself (top left) displays fine. However, when I ALT+TAB between the windows applications I see that the icon image displayed to select the active applications shows black instead of the semi-transparent pixels in the image. My guess is that SWT is not passing correctly the information to the OS in this case. The image itself looks fine on windows itself as an .ico file so I do not think this is a graphics issue. Can you attach the images please? Thanks. Created attachment 21998 Icon file that shows the problem. See black lines around icon when ALT+TAB Created attachment 22376 screenshot

Bug.Summery: Export ant build file doesn't parse variables in run targets correctly
Bug.WithStack:
Using 3.1M7 GTK.
Related to run targets which have arguments. I have an argument which consists of a variable, whose name contains spaces: ${project_loc:project name here}/somefile
In the ant build file, it is output as: <arg value="${project_loc:project"/> <arg value="name"/> <arg value="here}/somefile"/>
It would also need to insert the definition of the variable, as with classpath variables. Andrew is correc that there are two problems here: no expansion of the variables for program or vm arguments for all of the add* methods of BuildFileCreator
incorrect handling of strings with spaces in these arguments. BuildFileCreator.addElements(String, Document, Element, String, String) assumes that none of the values will contains strings.
Richard do you have time to work on these problems? You are right, currently only working directory is expanded. (Was already a TODO) And obviously I did not expect spaces... (Is now a TODO). I'm not sure if I have time this weekend. Created attachment 22390 Fixed source
Updated BuildFileCreator.addElements(String, Document, Element, String, String, Map): Uses org.apache.tools.ant.types.Commandline parser instead of StringTokenizer. This also handles quoted arguments.
BuildFileCreator.addVariable() now also supports several variables in one command line argument.
Note: User should always double quote a command line argument if it contains variables. If no double quotes are used by intention, because the variable expands to two command line arguments, it is not possible to create a matching Ant target: Nested <arg> can only contain one command line argument. Thanks Richard. Will review and consider for RC2 Richard...there is a problem with the quoting of variables in BuildFileCreator.addElements(String, Document, Element, String, String, Map)
Currently this code will fail with an argument such as: "${project_loc} project name here"
I am leaning towards having reliance on the user to properly quote the arguments. What are your thoughts? Darins, you are right. Remove the automatically inserted quotes. If there are really unbalanced quotes, we should carry the error message back to the user. For now I thinks it's okay to catch the exception. Sorry, somehow missed this testcase. Ok. I have altered the BuildFileCreator with Richard's patch and then modified to do error reporting on BuildExceptions from the Commandline usage.
Beefed up the error reporting in the AntBuildfileExportPage to report the exceptions to the user in the error message of the wizard.
Changes also to the DataTransferMessages and DataTransferMessages.properties for the NLS'ing Please verify Ryan and Richard. Darins, it works fine. Thanks. Marking verified.

Using 3.1M7 GTK.
Related to run targets which have arguments. I have an argument which consists of a variable, whose name contains spaces: ${project_loc:project name here}/somefile
In the ant build file, it is output as: <arg value="${project_loc:project"/> <arg value="name"/> <arg value="here}/somefile"/>
It would also need to insert the definition of the variable, as with classpath variables. Andrew is correc that there are two problems here: no expansion of the variables for program or vm arguments for all of the add* methods of BuildFileCreator
incorrect handling of strings with spaces in these arguments. BuildFileCreator.addElements(String, Document, Element, String, String) assumes that none of the values will contains strings.
Richard do you have time to work on these problems? You are right, currently only working directory is expanded. (Was already a TODO) And obviously I did not expect spaces... (Is now a TODO). I'm not sure if I have time this weekend. Created attachment 22390 Fixed source

Bug.Summery: [FastViews] New FastView bar looks out of place on non-Windows
Bug.WithStack:
On non-Windows platforms, the dots look strange. They don't match the platform look of a handle or grip. Even on Windows, the theme can change the appearance of the dots in handles. For example, the Windows "Gravity" theme uses lines rather than dotted lines. Since there is no SWT widget available for a "grab" widget, perhaps we should convert both the Welcome launcher and fast view bar to just a separator? Separator does not indicate moveability, so we would loose the visual indication that you can drag the widget. Personally, I thought it looked fine the way it was in 3.0. It seems late in the game to be introducing changes like this. Michael, I'll go with whatever you decide. The code shouldn't be too hard to tweak.
There is also the issue that when you have the perspective switcher and the fast view bar docked together (the 2.1 arrangement) then the bar looks noisy: perspective switcher -> no border, fast view bar -> border.
The appeal of the border is that in the empty case, i.e., when no fastviews are docked then it is more obvious that there is an area to dock views, but I have also heard the feedback that this looks like screen cheese.
Therefore the suggestion from Michael in comment #1 is appealing to me. Are we going to address this for 3.1 RC3? If we leave it the way it is, it looks funny on most platforms. If we put it back the way it was in 3.0, then we lose the moveability cue. I'd rather lose the cue but if the decision is to leave it the way it is, let's close this bug as WONTFIX. MVM and myself agreed to come up with a solution for RC3, so unless MVM changed his mind, we WILL address this to some extent. At this point in time the proposed solution should be brought to the attention of the PMC.
This change might impact the screenshots and people are starting to shoot them during RC3. Only affects two shots in EPG. Advance notice would be good though so I can warn the publisher of coming changes. we should have an answer by tomorrow, please hold me to this<grin> I always wondered why perspective switcher and dock view bar are not regular toolbars? It is also frustrating that you can only dock them now into predefined places and can't move around.
Same apply to the rest of toolbars. Why can't I stic toolbars to the left or right gaps where perspective and quick view bars can be docked?
Speaking about UI, if you going to keep this line around quick view bar, please make it look the same as perspective switcher bar. Currently there is no shadow on windows for quick view bar.
By the way, there is no visual indication that perspective switcher can be resized. It is not an issue in my view. I just think that old visual representation (toolbar-like) for quick view bar was fine and consistent with Windows UI.
+1 for comment #11. UI is working towards this, there are some restrictions with verical coolbars etc.. that we need to address first.
As a reference see also bug 97052. It was created due to the inconsistancies as opposed to the platform look so keeping this one open post 3.1 is the right thing to do. oops, I mean see also bug 97083
We're deprecating the FVB so no work is anticipated here...
BTW, the minimized stacks have their own 'border' affordance.

Bug.Summery: no provision for setting command-line make macros
Bug.WithStack:
Our makefile system assumes that some variables are set, either in the environment or on the command line. Even when I add these settings to the make command line in the project properties, the CDT fails to parse my makefiles since it runs afoul of ifdefs that demand the setting. Changing the make command or the make target to pass extra options works fine for me (I tried a simple test using DEBUG=-g and my make file contains a ${DEBUG}) Did you try a makefile that uses one of these macros as part of an included file pathname? That's the particular case that failed for me. The parse process failed.
my test was with the following makefile with the resulting output from the console below.
makefile: all: gcc -o loop loop.c -I/${INC}
clean: -rm loop
console output: make -k clean all INC=include rm loop gcc -o loop loop.c -I/include You need something like
include $(INC)/foo.mk
to see the problem.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Our makefile system assumes that some variables are set, either in the environment or on the command line. Even when I add these settings to the make command line in the project properties, the CDT fails to parse my makefiles since it runs afoul of ifdefs that demand the setting. Changing the make command or the make target to pass extra options works fine for me (I tried a simple test using DEBUG=-g and my make file contains a ${DEBUG}) Did you try a makefile that uses one of these macros as part of an included file pathname? That's the particular case that failed for me. The parse process failed.
my test was with the following makefile with the resulting output from the console below.
makefile: all: gcc -o loop loop.c -I/${INC}
clean: -rm loop
console output: make -k clean all INC=include rm loop gcc -o loop loop.c -I/include You need something like
include $(INC)/foo.mk
to see the problem.

Bug.Summery: [Help] Grey help window background

Lines.Line: 1) Setup a perspective with the Synchronize and CVS Repositories views in the
same tab group, with Synchronize on top.
2) Open the dynamic Help view and make it detached.
3) Shutdown and restartup
4) Wait until the Help view populates with the Sync view help
5) Click on the CVS Repositories view.

Bug.WithStack:
Build: I20050527-1300
I have been running with the dynamic help window open as a dynamic view. I have noticed sometimes when switching views that the contents for the new active view sometimes first appears with a grey background. After a second or two it redraws with a white background. This looks a bit ugly. I will attach a screen shot from when it is in this state. Here is one set of steps that reproduces it for me (I don't know if all these steps are necessary - shutting down, and tearing off the help view might not be necessary).
1) Setup a perspective with the Synchronize and CVS Repositories views in the same tab group, with Synchronize on top. 2) Open the dynamic Help view and make it detached. 3) Shutdown and restartup 4) Wait until the Help view populates with the Sync view help 5) Click on the CVS Repositories view.
-> The content appears with grey background, and then eventually redraws with white. Created attachment 21904 Screen shot of help view If it matters, my default browser is Firefox 1.0.
Also, I just tried without detaching the Help view, and saw the same problem. So it's unrelated to detached views. The code that renders the view is from Eclipse Forms - pure SWT (nothing to do with the browser). Not sure if this is related, but when I run a standalone help system in Firefox and my HTML documents do not have a background color set in their style, the topic pane shows gray. It looks like the same gray color as the help system UI frame.
I have not reported as it can be resolved by using a background color set to wihte (#FFFFFF) in the style sheet for the HTML topics, but it can be annoying. It only happens in Firefox. Mozilla and IE do not show it.
I'll attached some screen shots.
--Lee Anne Attaching two jpegs. One is the standalone help system with Firefox with a topic where the topic HTML file has no background color assigned to its body tag (or style sheet).
The second is the standalone help system in Firefox with the same topic, but with bgcolor="#ffffff" added to its <body> tag.
In the first, you'll notice that the gray color looks like the same gray as the help system frame in which the buttons (Print, etc) are.
--Lee Anne Created attachment 21909 Standalone help system in Firefox with HTML topic with no bgcolor set; Created attachment 21910 Standalone help system in Firefox with bgcolor="#ffffff" to HTML topic <body> tag John, is this really Win2k (I also assume it is 3.1, not 3.0.2 as specified in the bug). Yes, Win2k, build I20050527-1300. Lee Anne, the gray we are talking about here is in the Help view, not in the browser. I suggest opening a separate defect for the browser gray. I'm unable to reproduce, John are you still seeing this in Eclipse 3.3? No, I can't reproduce in 3.3 RC4. I'm now using Firefox 2.0.4 on Windows XP. Resolving as WORKSFORME, note also that the problem Lee Anne mentioned in comment 4 was fixed in Eclipse 3.3.
