I have been running with the dynamic help window open as a dynamic view. I have noticed sometimes when switching views that the contents for the new active view sometimes first appears with a grey background. After a second or two it redraws with a white background. This looks a bit ugly. I will attach a screen shot from when it is in this state. Here is one set of steps that reproduces it for me (I don't know if all these steps are necessary - shutting down, and tearing off the help view might not be necessary).
1) Setup a perspective with the Synchronize and CVS Repositories views in the same tab group, with Synchronize on top. 2) Open the dynamic Help view and make it detached. 3) Shutdown and restartup 4) Wait until the Help view populates with the Sync view help 5) Click on the CVS Repositories view.
-> The content appears with grey background, and then eventually redraws with white. Created attachment 21904 Screen shot of help view If it matters, my default browser is Firefox 1.0.
Also, I just tried without detaching the Help view, and saw the same problem. So it's unrelated to detached views. The code that renders the view is from Eclipse Forms - pure SWT (nothing to do with the browser). Not sure if this is related, but when I run a standalone help system in Firefox and my HTML documents do not have a background color set in their style, the topic pane shows gray. It looks like the same gray color as the help system UI frame.
I have not reported as it can be resolved by using a background color set to wihte (#FFFFFF) in the style sheet for the HTML topics, but it can be annoying. It only happens in Firefox. Mozilla and IE do not show it.
I'll attached some screen shots.
--Lee Anne Attaching two jpegs. One is the standalone help system with Firefox with a topic where the topic HTML file has no background color assigned to its body tag (or style sheet).
The second is the standalone help system in Firefox with the same topic, but with bgcolor="#ffffff" added to its <body> tag.
In the first, you'll notice that the gray color looks like the same gray as the help system frame in which the buttons (Print, etc) are.
--Lee Anne Created attachment 21909 Standalone help system in Firefox with HTML topic with no bgcolor set; Created attachment 21910 Standalone help system in Firefox with bgcolor="#ffffff" to HTML topic <body> tag John, is this really Win2k (I also assume it is 3.1, not 3.0.2 as specified in the bug). Yes, Win2k, build I20050527-1300. Lee Anne, the gray we are talking about here is in the Help view, not in the browser. I suggest opening a separate defect for the browser gray. I'm unable to reproduce, John are you still seeing this in Eclipse 3.3? No, I can't reproduce in 3.3 RC4. I'm now using Firefox 2.0.4 on Windows XP. Resolving as WORKSFORME, note also that the problem Lee Anne mentioned in comment 4 was fixed in Eclipse 3.3.

Bug.Summery: BackgroundLoader.java uses an internal eclipse class
Bug.WithStack:
o.e.h.ui plugin, BackgroundLoader class The StatusLineManager is retrieved using an internal eclipse class, WorkbenchWindow
StatusLineManager stm = ((WorkbenchWindow)HyadesUIPlugin.getInstance ().getWorkbench().getActiveWorkbenchWindow()).getStatusLineManager(); BTW, do you know a way to get the StatusLineManager instance using a public class? Use IStatusLineManager instead
You can get the StatusLineManager through the ActionBars on a view or editor part. In your case, since the backgroudLoader is an utiliy class to populate the SDView, make this call :
IStatusLineManager lineManager = _view.getViewSite().getActionBars ().getStatusLineManager();
You can get the _view from passing it to the loader or getting the view in focus from the workspace
Dominique, can you try to solve this in 4.0 ? This is the only internal API we use in TPTP ( or the only one I could identify so far )I am upgrating the severity to major since any chage in the StatusLineManager can break our code. Fixed in TPTP_HEAD for 4.0i4. Thanks for the information. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. Bug.Summery: Error while converting plugin to OSGi bundle
Bug.WithStack:
Using Eclipse 3.1 M7, I tried to convert a plugin into an OSGi bundle by clicking on the "create an OSGi bundle manifest" link in the Overview page of plugin.xml. I get an error dialog that I can't figure out:
Attempted to beginRule: R/. does not match outer scope rule: P/com.ibm.etools.environment.ui
My plugin's name is com.ibm.etools.environment.ui but what does the error message mean?
If I refresh the project, it appears that the bundle is created but not all changes have occurred. For example build.properties was not updated. was this a single occurrence or reproducible? I would need to have steps
This is reproducible but I will have to modify my code to remove confidential information and then try to create a testcase. John, what does the message about rules in the initial comment mean? To reproduce, we really don't need any Java code. Just a minimal project with all the .* files and the plugin.xml/build.properties files would o. After some investigation, I believe that my repository, IBM CMVC, may have something to do with this problem. It seems to occur only when my plugin is shared with the IBM CMVC repository. If the error is not coming from Eclipse then it could be coming from the repository provider in which case I could puruse it with them. Otherwise, you need access to a CMVC repository in order to reproduce this. Re comment #3. See this link for an answer to the same question:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=91333#c6
I need to write a FAQ for this... Was able to reproduce with the Team sample pessimistic provider. The scheduling rule passed to IProgressService#runInUI was causing the problem. Fixed.

Bug.Summery: (Plat) Fix Plugin Translatability Log problems

Lines.Line: 1. For files with a "115" error, add this comment to the start of the file
# NLS_ENCODING=UTF-8
2. For files with a "964" error, ensure that the correct encoding is specified:
<?xml encoding="UTF-8" version="1.0" ?>
3. For files with a "119" error, see if the file should be translated, and if
not, once the errors in the other files are fixed, then transfer this defect
to the build team so that they can exclude the file from the translation check.
4. For files with a "920" error, add one of the following comments to the file
to indicate what type of single quote handling should be used:
# NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_ALL
# NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_NONE
# NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_VAR
Choose which comment to use based on this criteria:
NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_ALL
Each string is assumed to be processed by the java.text.MessageFormat class
(single quote must be coded as 2 consecutive single quotes '').
NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_NONE
All strings are assumed to NOT be processed by the java.text.MessageFormat
class (single quote must be coded as 1 single quote ').
NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_VAR
Strings which contain replacement variables are processed by the
MessageFormat class (single quote must be coded as 2 consecutive single quotes
''). Strings which do NOT contain replacement variables are NOT processed by the
MessageFormat class (single quote must be coded as 1 single quote ').
Dup of bug 98958

Bug.Summery: API: ReportDescription class uses a deprecated interface
Bug.WithStack:
The IReportDescription interface has been deprecated and replaced by ReportGeneratorWizard
ReportDescription is still using the deprecated interface; it should be updated to work with the new class As a comment, I find this deprecation unusual.. if I have a class A which implements the IReportGenerator interface and also extends my own class B, there is no easy way I can remove the deprecation and move A to extend the ReportGeneratorWizard class. I have to choose between my B class and the new class provided by the TPTP framework We should at least remove the deprecated call from the TPTP code so other users have a sample on how to update their code. To fix the problems, please do the following: 1. For files with a "115" error, add this comment to the start of the file # NLS_ENCODING=UTF-8 2. For files with a "920" error, add one of the following comments to the file to indicate what type of single quote handling should be used: # NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_ALL # NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_NONE # NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_VAR Choose which comment to use based on this criteria: NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_ALL Each string is assumed to be processed by the java.text.MessageFormat class (single quote must be coded as 2 consecutive single quotes ''). NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_NONE All strings are assumed to NOT be processed by the java.text.MessageFormat class (single quote must be coded as 1 single quote '). NLS_MESSAGEFORMAT_VAR Strings which contain replacement variables are processed by the MessageFormat class (single quote must be coded as 2 consecutive single quotes ''). Strings which do NOT contain replacement variables are NOT processed by the MessageFormat class (single quote must be coded as 1 single quote '). Changes committed to 4.0 Head CVS. Bug.Summery: [Forms] ScrolledForm explodes Text widget size
Bug.WithStack:
Enter more than one line of text in the site.xml editor. Either save, resize or stretch the editor. The String within the Text widget is forced to a single line and stretched horizontally.
We are experiencing this problem with our RCP application when placing a Text widget with WRAP | V_SCROLL style bits within a ScrolledForm. Both Text and StyledText widgets share the same odd behavior. Are you entering this line in the source page or the GUI page? (In reply to comment #1) > Are you entering this line in the source page or the GUI page?
I entered into the GUI page. If you enter into the source page then you get the same results. If entered into the GUI as I did you can visually see the funky behavior by stretching or expanding the editor - or by saving the editor. I think this is a bug when wordwrap enabled Text widgets are placed in a ScrolledForm. But the source page is not in a scrolled form, and you say that you get the same result. (In reply to comment #3) > But the source page is not in a scrolled form, and you say that you get the > same result.
I appologize - the form I am referring to is on the "Archives" tab of the site.xml editor. This is most likely a PDE issue - need to assign width hint for the text widget to prevent it from stretching as wide as needed to show the text in one line. Fixed. Not fixed - scrollbars were only removed. Now I cannot see all my text. also - when I save after adding text it does not wrap or scroll my text, it expands horizontally onto a single line (See original description). This is a more general problem than just the site.xml editor. All of our RCP application's ScrolledForms blow out the horizontal size of Text widgets that contain very long lines of text. It seems that the Text is being horizontally sized to accomodate the entire line even when you specify SWT.WRAP or SWT.H_SCROLL. This defeats the entire purpose of using scrollbars. Removing the scrollbars is not an option for our users.
Set to Blocker because it blocks us from using Scrollbars. This is really a problem for our RCP app. Is there a workaround for this bug? When you specify Text widget, do you use SWT.MULTI style as well? Without it, you will always get one line of text (text field). In those cases, the recommended way to deal with long strings is to set the minimum/preferred size of the widget so something small (say, 100). This will render the widget nicely with respect to the overall page. It WILL cut off the text but you can still read the entire text - just click in the field and move the cursor to the right using the right arrow key.
If, on the other hand, you want the entire text to be visible, you need to create a Text widget with SWT.MULTI style and use SWT.WRAP.
Since we are wrapping up 3.2, either reduce the severity of the defect or let us know if the suggestions above work for you. Reducing severity to normal due to the age of the bug and the definition of 'blocker' severity. Reproduced on 3.4 RC3. Using SWT.WRAP | SWT.MULTI still does not cause the text to wrap. I had to add a widthHint to the Text to force it use multiple lines and wrap. This is not ideal as it requires you to know the desired width at development time. See the discussion in Bug 265389, I think this is the same problem but since I'm not 100% sure of that I will not close either bug out as a duplicate.

Bug.Summery: Add toolbar buttons for creating fast views and detaching

source_code.code: public boolean canMoveTo(IPresentablePart part, int location);

Lines.Line: 1. Makes it more obvious how to reattach a detached view
2. Makes it more efficient to create a fast view / detached view
3. Makes it easier to discover fast views and detached views
Cons:
4. Makes it harder to discover the view menu
5. Adds visual clutter
6. Makes it easier to change states by accident
7. Uses extra screen real-estate
Suggestions:
8. Keep the view menu next to the new location icons
9. Do not change the fast view icon based on the location of the fast view bar.
10. Provide a faster gesture for reattaching a view from the fast view bar.
Summary:
11. Make this feature avalable as an option, but disable it by default.
12. Keep the new API, even if we don't use the new icons.
13. Wait until 3.2 before adding this patch.
14. Keep the reattach button for detached views.
1. With the current detached view appearance, it is not easy to tell how to
reattach views. The patch greatly improves this issue, which justifies (at
minimum) including the reattach button for detached views (item 14).
2. The buttons make it significantly quicker to create fast views and detached
views. This is not important since (it is assumed that) most users will
initially get the layout the way they like it and then infrequently tweak views
between the three states. However, this is probably not true of all users and
those that are continually tweaking their layout would find it useful.
This would justify including the new buttons (at least) as an option for
power-users (item 11).
(Aside: Since I'm the guy who wrote the current workbench layout, fast view bar,
and detached view code, I am continually rearranging my layout for testing.
However, I believe that I am a minority and that most users do not rearrange
their layout frequently).
3. The new buttons make it easier to discover the fast view bar and detached
views. This is true, but not necessarily an advantage. Fundamentally, we should
give buttons prominent screen real-estate because they are frequently used, not
because they are hard to discover. We could help with discovery of the fast view
bar by including something like the "tips and tricks" popup found in many other
apps, and by adding a more obvious affordance for opening the system menu.
4. By putting a lot of icons in this area, the view menu becomes less prominent.
Eclipse is fully functional without fast views or detached windows, but is
severely crippled without the view menu.
5. The new icons make the UI look much more cluttered.
6. A new user is likely to have a negative reaction if they create a fast view
by accident while still trying to figure out the basics of creating a project,
editing text, and running their program. A more advanced user is likely to find
them useful, but it is reasonable if they don't discover the feature until
they've started exploring the UI for ways to optimize screen space.
7. The new icons take up extra screen space. This is not a significant
disadvantage because in most cases the space is unused anyway.
8. We should decide what our criteria are for including something in the top
right of the folder (as opposed to dropping down with the view's toolbar). If
this space is reserved for system contributions, then both the view menu and the
new location buttons should go there. If this space is for actions that affect
the whole stack, then neither the view menu nor the new buttons belong there.
The mockup I was given showed the new buttons up top and the view menu below,
which doesn't seem consistent by either criteria. The current patch moves both
down with the toolbar. Changing this would require new API on CTabFolder
(Veronika says she has a patch ready).
9. The mockup I was given showed the different icons for the Make Fast View
button depending on the current location of the fast view bar. This makes sense
in apps that have something similar to multiple fast view bars, since the icon
would indicate which bar will receive the fast view. However, in Eclipse there
is only one meaning for Make Fast View, and once the user has learned to
recognize its icon, we shouldn't change it on them just because the fast view
bar moved. I haven't had time to code the changing icons yet, but would advise
against it in any case.
10. Now that there is a fast gesture to create a fast view, there should be an
equally fast gesture to undo that action. I would suggest allowing users to
re-dock fast views by double-clicking on the fast view's icon. Nick suggested
also removing the current ability to hide the view by clicking on an open fast
view's icon to avoid introducing temporal modes. This gesture is redundant
anyway since the user can also hide the fast view by clicking virtually anywhere
else on the window.
Summary:
11. I believe this is a potentally useful feature for certain experienced users,
but it will be intimidating to new users. As such, I recommend including as an
option but disabling by default.
12. The new API gives presentations control over the fast view creation gesture.
This is useful for RCP and we should keep it even if we decide not to use it
ourselves.
13. The patch is big and risky (getting the layout right is really tricky). This
is also the type of thing we should gather some community feedback on before
including it in a major release. I'd suggest deferring until early in 3.2.
- Adds system icons for detaching, creating fast views, and docking.
- Changes the system menu to match the toolbar buttons (they get matching icons
and are no longer toggles. For example, detached views have "fast view" and
"attach" items rather than a checked "detached" item that moves the view to its
previous location)
- The new icons are aligned with the view menu.
- Three new constants in IWorkbenchPartConstants (not sure if this is the best
place for them or not)
- IStackPresentationSite gets property change listeners (with selection and
disposed events)
- IStackPresentationSite gets the following:
- There needs to be a protocol for presentations to hide the old system menu
actions for detaching and fast views
Known bugs:
- There are several layout problems (the toolbar will sometimes end up missing
or in the wrong spot).
- The icons are wrong (I just grabbed random icons)

Bug.WithStack:
I've been asked to provide a demo of using buttons for toggling views between detached, fast view, and docked.
This PR is intended for tracking the state of the patch and discussing the merits of the feature. Created attachment 21907 Rough demo (patch for workbench)
This patch implements a rough demo of the feature. Not production quality yet.
Behavioral changes: - Adds system icons for detaching, creating fast views, and docking. - Changes the system menu to match the toolbar buttons (they get matching icons and are no longer toggles. For example, detached views have "fast view" and "attach" items rather than a checked "detached" item that moves the view to its previous location) - The new icons are aligned with the view menu.
API changes: - Three new constants in IWorkbenchPartConstants (not sure if this is the best place for them or not) - IStackPresentationSite gets property change listeners (with selection and disposed events) - IStackPresentationSite gets the following:
public boolean canMoveTo(IPresentablePart part, int location); public void moveTo(IPresentablePart part, int location) public int getLocation();
- There needs to be a protocol for presentations to hide the old system menu actions for detaching and fast views Known bugs: - There are several layout problems (the toolbar will sometimes end up missing or in the wrong spot). - The icons are wrong (I just grabbed random icons)
IWorkbenchPartConstants is for properties on regular views and editors. Should put the new constants in the presentations API, presumably close to where the min and max constants are.
Nick: I agree that this might not be the best place for the constants, but they are much more useful than just for the presentation API. Universal constants for docking locations would also be useful for IWorkbenchPage, IPageLayout, and any other workbench class that currently distinguishes between fast/detached/docked. These states are not currently exposed to regular plug-ins. But if you think there's a good chance they may be in the future, I'm OK with it.
My analysis of the new feature. First the quick version:
Pros: 1. Makes it more obvious how to reattach a detached view 2. Makes it more efficient to create a fast view / detached view 3. Makes it easier to discover fast views and detached views
Cons: 4. Makes it harder to discover the view menu 5. Adds visual clutter 6. Makes it easier to change states by accident 7. Uses extra screen real-estate
Suggestions: 8. Keep the view menu next to the new location icons 9. Do not change the fast view icon based on the location of the fast view bar. 10. Provide a faster gesture for reattaching a view from the fast view bar.
Summary: 11. Make this feature avalable as an option, but disable it by default. 12. Keep the new API, even if we don't use the new icons. 13. Wait until 3.2 before adding this patch. 14. Keep the reattach button for detached views.
Now the long version:
1. With the current detached view appearance, it is not easy to tell how to reattach views. The patch greatly improves this issue, which justifies (at minimum) including the reattach button for detached views (item 14).
2. The buttons make it significantly quicker to create fast views and detached views. This is not important since (it is assumed that) most users will initially get the layout the way they like it and then infrequently tweak views between the three states. However, this is probably not true of all users and those that are continually tweaking their layout would find it useful.
This would justify including the new buttons (at least) as an option for power-users (item 11).
(Aside: Since I'm the guy who wrote the current workbench layout, fast view bar, and detached view code, I am continually rearranging my layout for testing. However, I believe that I am a minority and that most users do not rearrange their layout frequently).
3. The new buttons make it easier to discover the fast view bar and detached views. This is true, but not necessarily an advantage. Fundamentally, we should give buttons prominent screen real-estate because they are frequently used, not because they are hard to discover. We could help with discovery of the fast view bar by including something like the "tips and tricks" popup found in many other apps, and by adding a more obvious affordance for opening the system menu.
4. By putting a lot of icons in this area, the view menu becomes less prominent. Eclipse is fully functional without fast views or detached windows, but is severely crippled without the view menu.
5. The new icons make the UI look much more cluttered.
6. A new user is likely to have a negative reaction if they create a fast view by accident while still trying to figure out the basics of creating a project, editing text, and running their program. A more advanced user is likely to find them useful, but it is reasonable if they don't discover the feature until they've started exploring the UI for ways to optimize screen space.
7. The new icons take up extra screen space. This is not a significant disadvantage because in most cases the space is unused anyway.
8. We should decide what our criteria are for including something in the top right of the folder (as opposed to dropping down with the view's toolbar). If this space is reserved for system contributions, then both the view menu and the new location buttons should go there. If this space is for actions that affect the whole stack, then neither the view menu nor the new buttons belong there. The mockup I was given showed the new buttons up top and the view menu below, which doesn't seem consistent by either criteria. The current patch moves both down with the toolbar. Changing this would require new API on CTabFolder (Veronika says she has a patch ready).
9. The mockup I was given showed the different icons for the Make Fast View button depending on the current location of the fast view bar. This makes sense in apps that have something similar to multiple fast view bars, since the icon would indicate which bar will receive the fast view. However, in Eclipse there is only one meaning for Make Fast View, and once the user has learned to recognize its icon, we shouldn't change it on them just because the fast view bar moved. I haven't had time to code the changing icons yet, but would advise against it in any case.
10. Now that there is a fast gesture to create a fast view, there should be an equally fast gesture to undo that action. I would suggest allowing users to re-dock fast views by double-clicking on the fast view's icon. Nick suggested also removing the current ability to hide the view by clicking on an open fast view's icon to avoid introducing temporal modes. This gesture is redundant anyway since the user can also hide the fast view by clicking virtually anywhere else on the window.
Summary:
11. I believe this is a potentally useful feature for certain experienced users, but it will be intimidating to new users. As such, I recommend including as an option but disabling by default.
12. The new API gives presentations control over the fast view creation gesture. This is useful for RCP and we should keep it even if we decide not to use it ourselves.
13. The patch is big and risky (getting the layout right is really tricky). This is also the type of thing we should gather some community feedback on before including it in a major release. I'd suggest deferring until early in 3.2.
Re: comment 5
I agree they should move. Do we have any other repository for workbench constants? I'd like to avoid creating yet another class (classloading is already slow enough), but agree that they don't really fit in where they are.
Created attachment 21914 Screenshot including a docked view, a detached view, and a fast view
Screenshot of the new buttons (the location and function is correct, but the actual icons will change). We have the constants for max/min/restore on IStackPresentationSite. Although the location is per-part state, not stack state, the API to query/change locations is on IStackPresentationSite, so how about just adding the constants there?
Also noticed that some of the new API is missing @since tags.
Created attachment 21989 fixes missing icons
Fixes an icon problem in the original patch. Created attachment 21990 updates the test suites to compile with the new changes Reassigning the last of Stefan's bugs.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I've been asked to provide a demo of using buttons for toggling views between detached, fast view, and docked.
This PR is intended for tracking the state of the patch and discussing the merits of the feature. Created attachment 21907 Rough demo (patch for workbench)
This patch implements a rough demo of the feature. Not production quality yet.
Behavioral changes: - Adds system icons for detaching, creating fast views, and docking. - Changes the system menu to match the toolbar buttons (they get matching icons and are no longer toggles. For example, detached views have "fast view" and "attach" items rather than a checked "detached" item that moves the view to its previous location) - The new icons are aligned with the view menu.
API changes: - Three new constants in IWorkbenchPartConstants (not sure if this is the best place for them or not) - IStackPresentationSite gets property change listeners (with selection and disposed events) - IStackPresentationSite gets the following:
public boolean canMoveTo(IPresentablePart part, int location); public void moveTo(IPresentablePart part, int location) public int getLocation();
- There needs to be a protocol for presentations to hide the old system menu actions for detaching and fast views Known bugs: - There are several layout problems (the toolbar will sometimes end up missing or in the wrong spot). - The icons are wrong (I just grabbed random icons)
IWorkbenchPartConstants is for properties on regular views and editors. Should put the new constants in the presentations API, presumably close to where the min and max constants are.
Nick: I agree that this might not be the best place for the constants, but they are much more useful than just for the presentation API. Universal constants for docking locations would also be useful for IWorkbenchPage, IPageLayout, and any other workbench class that currently distinguishes between fast/detached/docked. These states are not currently exposed to regular plug-ins. But if you think there's a good chance they may be in the future, I'm OK with it.
My analysis of the new feature. First the quick version:
Pros: 1. Makes it more obvious how to reattach a detached view 2. Makes it more efficient to create a fast view / detached view 3. Makes it easier to discover fast views and detached views
Cons: 4. Makes it harder to discover the view menu 5. Adds visual clutter 6. Makes it easier to change states by accident 7. Uses extra screen real-estate
Suggestions: 8. Keep the view menu next to the new location icons 9. Do not change the fast view icon based on the location of the fast view bar. 10. Provide a faster gesture for reattaching a view from the fast view bar.
Summary: 11. Make this feature avalable as an option, but disable it by default. 12. Keep the new API, even if we don't use the new icons. 13. Wait until 3.2 before adding this patch. 14. Keep the reattach button for detached views.
Now the long version:
1. With the current detached view appearance, it is not easy to tell how to reattach views. The patch greatly improves this issue, which justifies (at minimum) including the reattach button for detached views (item 14).
2. The buttons make it significantly quicker to create fast views and detached views. This is not important since (it is assumed that) most users will initially get the layout the way they like it and then infrequently tweak views between the three states. However, this is probably not true of all users and those that are continually tweaking their layout would find it useful.
This would justify including the new buttons (at least) as an option for power-users (item 11).
(Aside: Since I'm the guy who wrote the current workbench layout, fast view bar, and detached view code, I am continually rearranging my layout for testing. However, I believe that I am a minority and that most users do not rearrange their layout frequently).
3. The new buttons make it easier to discover the fast view bar and detached views. This is true, but not necessarily an advantage. Fundamentally, we should give buttons prominent screen real-estate because they are frequently used, not because they are hard to discover. We could help with discovery of the fast view bar by including something like the "tips and tricks" popup found in many other apps, and by adding a more obvious affordance for opening the system menu.
4. By putting a lot of icons in this area, the view menu becomes less prominent. Eclipse is fully functional without fast views or detached windows, but is severely crippled without the view menu.
5. The new icons make the UI look much more cluttered.
6. A new user is likely to have a negative reaction if they create a fast view by accident while still trying to figure out the basics of creating a project, editing text, and running their program. A more advanced user is likely to find them useful, but it is reasonable if they don't discover the feature until they've started exploring the UI for ways to optimize screen space.
7. The new icons take up extra screen space. This is not a significant disadvantage because in most cases the space is unused anyway.
8. We should decide what our criteria are for including something in the top right of the folder (as opposed to dropping down with the view's toolbar). If this space is reserved for system contributions, then both the view menu and the new location buttons should go there. If this space is for actions that affect the whole stack, then neither the view menu nor the new buttons belong there. The mockup I was given showed the new buttons up top and the view menu below, which doesn't seem consistent by either criteria. The current patch moves both down with the toolbar. Changing this would require new API on CTabFolder (Veronika says she has a patch ready).
9. The mockup I was given showed the different icons for the Make Fast View button depending on the current location of the fast view bar. This makes sense in apps that have something similar to multiple fast view bars, since the icon would indicate which bar will receive the fast view. However, in Eclipse there is only one meaning for Make Fast View, and once the user has learned to recognize its icon, we shouldn't change it on them just because the fast view bar moved. I haven't had time to code the changing icons yet, but would advise against it in any case.
10. Now that there is a fast gesture to create a fast view, there should be an equally fast gesture to undo that action. I would suggest allowing users to re-dock fast views by double-clicking on the fast view's icon. Nick suggested also removing the current ability to hide the view by clicking on an open fast view's icon to avoid introducing temporal modes. This gesture is redundant anyway since the user can also hide the fast view by clicking virtually anywhere else on the window.
Summary:
11. I believe this is a potentally useful feature for certain experienced users, but it will be intimidating to new users. As such, I recommend including as an option but disabling by default.
12. The new API gives presentations control over the fast view creation gesture. This is useful for RCP and we should keep it even if we decide not to use it ourselves.
13. The patch is big and risky (getting the layout right is really tricky). This is also the type of thing we should gather some community feedback on before including it in a major release. I'd suggest deferring until early in 3.2.
Re: comment 5
I agree they should move. Do we have any other repository for workbench constants? I'd like to avoid creating yet another class (classloading is already slow enough), but agree that they don't really fit in where they are.
Created attachment 21914 Screenshot including a docked view, a detached view, and a fast view
Screenshot of the new buttons (the location and function is correct, but the actual icons will change). We have the constants for max/min/restore on IStackPresentationSite. Although the location is per-part state, not stack state, the API to query/change locations is on IStackPresentationSite, so how about just adding the constants there?
Also noticed that some of the new API is missing @since tags.

Bug.Summery: silently stoping download on http 404
Bug.WithStack:
when update starts downloading selected features and plug-ins if it doesn't find one of them on the webserver it will silently stop download and not report anything to the user. There will be excpetion with http 404 error in the log. User should be informed of this. possible candidate for rc2 Created attachment 23327 update operation failed pop-up window
could you guys(Dejan, Dorian, Konrad) check it, it happens with http://update.eclipse.org/testUpdates/ (choose last category) this is slow so you can test it with site created by you just delete plug-in jar. Without patch it should stop without any worning and with patch there should be a pop-up window informing you that update operation has failed. I think this is very important for user experience, since when originally happened to me i was very confused. There is no risk that i could see, so I think it is very safe patch. the patch looks ok... has it been tested on regular install, automatic updates and scan for updates (in config manager window) ?
The patch constains changes to ReviewPage. How they relate to this bug?
The change to InstallWizard2 is OK (except unused import). It produces a simple mesage dialog - better than nothing.
During tesing i disconnected the network and was presented with a different error dialog. So some code is already there to report an error, but does not cover all failure scenarios. The new dialog shows up when features do not exist. It would be best to consolidate these dialogs. But for 3.1 I think this is fine. +1. provided I read some explanation of changes to ReviewPage. Created attachment 23342 update operation failed pop-up window
Dorian, i tested for regular install as for scan for updates it's exaclty the same code path as regular install so i do not see any reason to test in that set up. Do you see any problems with other scenarios or you would just like to me tested more? Konrad, you are right that's half a fix for another bug(gone now). no, I don't anticipate any problems, but at this point in time we need to get a good test coverage, and those would be the main execution paths. Now is the perfect time to be paranoid and test even though you know the code uses the same branches. +1. For the code in the patch. Branko, Please perform more testing to obtain +1 from component owner. finally i tested it and it worked from update manager and automatic updates thanks Branko!
+1 for RC3 Released. Looks like the map made in into 4pm build. :-)

Bug.Summery: Consolidate developer docs in one place
Bug.WithStack: Documents have been written by developers (getting_started, install, samples, etc., ) and need to be shipped to customers, but are currently not owned by ID nor consolidated into a single location. This means that docs that should be translated are not translated. All of these docs need to be organized, consistent, consolidated into a single location, and owned by a single person (ID). Bug.Summery: TableColumn should be multi-line
Bug.WithStack: It would be usefull if we can affect to a TableColumn a kind of SWT.MULTI, SWT.WRAP style so a long text could be display in a row. The height of changing accordingly. Linux/GTK implementation of table column can be easily made multiline inserting "\n" into text - should work in current implementations. Windows implementation for this would be very tricky. In Win32 programming people either replace table control or table header control to get this functionality or create all kind of tricks to full ListView32 window to allow multiliner. I did a quick research for this Win32 problem and did not see any easy solution. I don't expect it to be solved any time soon. I think in some cases its a very useful thing, if i have the possibility to wrap the text im my Tableheaders.
Bug.WithOutStack: It would be usefull if we can affect to a TableColumn a kind of SWT.MULTI, SWT.WRAP style so a long text could be display in a row. The height of changing accordingly. Linux/GTK implementation of table column can be easily made multiline inserting "\n" into text - should work in current implementations. Windows implementation for this would be very tricky. In Win32 programming people either replace table control or table header control to get this functionality or create all kind of tricks to full ListView32 window to allow multiliner. I did a quick research for this Win32 problem and did not see any easy solution. I don't expect it to be solved any time soon. I think in some cases its a very useful thing, if i have the possibility to wrap the text im my Tableheaders.

Bug.Summery: [Open Definition] with C project and DOM Indexer opens reference instead of definition for simple example
Bug.WithStack:
Using the DOM Indexer with a C Project:
// test.h: int x; // test.c: int foo() { return x; // F2 on x should highlight x in test.h and not the x in test.c } External variables are no longer supported.
However there is still a problem with external functions.
// test.h: int x() {return 1;} // test.c: int f() {return x();} // F2/F3 on x should find the x in test.h
DOM Indexer: F2 fails, F3 works Original Indexer: F2 fails, F3 works CTags Indexer: F2 works, F3 fails
Moving to RC1 since depending PR is moved to RC1. This is still on M7, not RC1. Second example with DOM indexer now yields: F2 works, F3 fails
I would say that this is correct behaviour and we should rethink what F3 (open declaration) means in C/C++ world. Opening a definition (F2) is what makes sense, since there could be multiple declarations but only one definition of an element.
To do it properly:
Open Declaration will do a search on both declarations and definitions. If it finds more than one occurrence it shall bring up a dialog for the user to choose which one s/he wants. Open Declaration/Open Definition are not meant to bring up dialogs. The gesture is meant to go to the AST construct that makes the most sense. If there are multiple declarations then the Open Declaration Action (not the indexer) picks the one that it thinks fits best. Throwing up a dialog interferes with the workflow.
So is this bug still open or is there a new bug? That's OK for Open Definition, not so good for Open Declaration. Why is picking the first item returned in the list the "right" item? In general the first item found is returned (which should be the first declaration). This may not be the best choice all of the time but unless someone complains about it with a good reason then that's the way it is. It's a bad idea to open a dialog for the quick 'jump to' features F2/F3 since the user can use Search or All Declarations to get a list of the results if F2/F3 isn't the one they wanted.
This bug isn't fixed ... but for the purpose of closing M7 it might be best to push it aside (or move it to RC1 anyways) since I don't consider it to be a show stopper.
When I create a new Standard Make C Project the DOM Indexer doesn't seem to run. I try to build the project but no #includes are picked up, and the DOM Indexer still doesn't run.
I just tried the latest from HEAD with the following results:
// test.h: int x() {return 1;} // test.c: int f() {return x();} // F2/F3 on x should find the x in test.h
DOM Indexer: F2 fails, F3 fails CTags Indexer: F2 fails, F3 fails
Ok, the behaviour you see is the matter of facts. The reason is as follows: When a new standard make project is created default value for indexer is 'Full indexer' aka DOM indexer. Also default for SCD is 'Per file discovery'. In this case building a project without a proper make file will not yield any discovered info, therefore the indexer will skip all files that do not have any scanner info (which is all files in this case).
To be able to exercise the test case, please switch to 'Per project discovery' before building the project.

Bug.Summery: AJDT forces open Plugin.xml Editor / Build when enabling Aspect Nature
Bug.WithStack:
Does this have to be done? I know what it is doing. I don't need the plugin.xml open. Also, it seems to force a build. I want to do a full build after I've turned all my natures on. This runs much faster than a, then b, then c all running when I select several projects at once and turn things on. Yes, opening the plugin.xml in the editor is undesirable - it is just a side-effect of the way we add the org.aspectj.runtime dependency. We'll see if there is a way to add it without opening the editor.
I guess a build should be forced if "build automatically" is on, but it shouldn't if this is off. Are you seeing forced builds even when "build automatically" is off? I'm fairly sure this needs to be done. We definitely want to avoid having to do anything like parsing the plugin.xml file. However I have not looked into it in that much depth so I'm returning it to the pool for now. Do we open still open plugin.xml when adding AspectJ nature? Yes, the manifest editor is being opened automatically whenever the AJ nature is added or removed from a plugin project. I will be attaching a patch that will automatically close the editor after the AJ nature has been added or removed (if it was not already opened before the operation started). This will mean that the programmer will see a flicker of the editor opening and then closing, but it seems that it is necessary for the editor to be opened in order to ensure consistency when the required plugins are changed.
As for builds, it does not seem that a build is being forced even when automatic builds are turned off. If automatic builds are turned on, then it seems entirely reasonable that a full build is required after adding or removing the AJ nature. So, I am not touching this part. Created attachment 102035 With this patch, the manifest editor will be closed immediately after adding or removing AJ Nature (if it wasn't already open beforehand). Created attachment 102036 mylyn/context/zip fix committed.
iplog

Bug.Summery: [CheatSheets] [RCP] Cheat sheets plug-in should not depend on IDE menu structure

source_code.code: // See ExtensionFactory for a similar implementation

Lines.Line: 1) Move the class 'CheatSheetHelpMenuAction' to org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets
package and add all the required Javadoc to make it real API.
2) Move Cheatsheet action set to org.eclipse.platform plugin.xml.
- We need to expose cheat sheet action via an extension factory.
- We will use the factory to contribute the action set in org.eclipse.sdk
plugin.xml
- Other products will be able to do the same, but we will not add the action
set for free for all the people that simply add the cheat sheets plug-in into
their RCP.

Bug.WithStack:
I didn't use to get these errors in the past.
When I start my RCP application, I get:
Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): converstLineDelimitersTo Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.edit.text.delimiter.macOS9 Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.edit.text.delimiter.unix Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.edit.text.delimiter.windows Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.edit.text.openExternalFile Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.update.ui.updateMenu Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.update.ui.configManager Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.update.ui.newUpdates Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.actions.showKeyAssistHandler Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.edit.text.gotoLastEditPosition Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.actions.CheatSheetHelpMenuAction Looks like you're including IDE plug-ins that make assumptions about the menu structure. Do you include org.eclipse.ui.editors?
For the CheatSheetHelpMenuAction, this appears to be coming from org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets itself. It should not make assumptions about the menu structure, since cheatsheets is intended to be an optional RCP component.
Here is my required plugins: <requires> <import plugin="org.eclipse.core.runtime"/> <import plugin="org.eclipse.swt"/> <import plugin="org.formulachess.chess.utils"/> <import plugin="org.eclipse.jface"/> <import plugin="org.formulachess.chess.ui"/> <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.workbench"/> <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.views"/> </requires>
I don't know what to change to get rid of these. My point was that in the past this used to work without errors. Also I lost the icon when I run in self-hosting. The update.ui.* and org.eclipse.ui.actions.showKeyAssistHandler come from org.eclipse.ui.ide, which should also not be included in RCP apps.
You should include org.eclipse.ui instead of org.eclipse.ui.workbench. It re-exports SWT, JFace and ui.workbench, so the following should suffice:
<requires> <import plugin="org.eclipse.core.runtime"/> <import plugin="org.formulachess.chess.utils"/> <import plugin="org.formulachess.chess.ui"/> <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui"/> <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.views"/> </requires>
But I suspect the problem is with the launch config, not your plugin.xml. On the plug-ins tab, press Deselect All, select your chess plug-ins, then Add Required and try Validate Plug-in Set.
You are right. Your suggested change reduced the list. But I still get: Invalid Menu Extension (Path is invalid): org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.actions.CheatSheetHelpMenuAction
And I don't see the icon. The remaining error was apparently due to a stale config. Cleaning the target's config fixed the problem.
Lorne, please consider this for RC2. See comment 1 for the problem. I suggest moving the action set to the ide plug-in.
Actually, it might make more sense to put the action set in the SDK plug-in, not o.e.ui.ide.
CheatSheetHelpMenuAction is internal (org.eclipse.ui.internal.cheatsheets.actions.CheatSheetHelpMenuAction). The action's implementation is trivial and it would be easy to move it to org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets as API, but we would need approval for it.
If approved, I would:
1) Move the class 'CheatSheetHelpMenuAction' to org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets package and add all the required Javadoc to make it real API.
2) Move Cheatsheet action set to org.eclipse.platform plugin.xml.
Note that if you want to expose the action without exposing its implementation class, you can use the extension factory mechanism. See org.eclipse.core.runtime.IExecutableExtensionFactory, org.eclipse.ui.ExtensionFactory, and how it's used in org.eclipse.ui.ide's plugin.xml.
This would still require an API exemption to provide a cheat sheets extension factory as API.
Jim, request for API exception:
- We need to expose cheat sheet action via an extension factory. - We will use the factory to contribute the action set in org.eclipse.sdk plugin.xml - Other products will be able to do the same, but we will not add the action set for free for all the people that simply add the cheat sheets plug-in into their RCP.
The proposed API:
org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.CheatSheetExtensionFactory
It will implement IExecutableExtensionFactory and used for the action set in the following way:
<extension point="org.eclipse.ui.actionSets"> <actionSet label="%CHEAT_SHEETS" visible="true" id="org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.actionSet"> <action label="%CHEAT_SHEETS_MENU" class="org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.CheatSheetExtensionFactory:helpMenuAction" menubarPath="help/group.tutorials" id="org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.actions.CheatSheetHelpMenuAction"> </action> </actionSet> </extension>
public class CheatSheetExtensionFactory public class ExtensionFactory implements IExecutableExtensionFactory, IExecutableExtension {
// See ExtensionFactory for a similar implementation } API approved for 3.1 RC2. Be sure to include complete API specs and schema, and tag as @since 3.1. Done.

Bug.Summery: [Intro] Minimized intro and fast view bar appear with different grab bars

Lines.Line: 1) Use the same algorithm to render grab bars so that there is no difference
between fast views and Intro
2) Render the grab bars only on Windows. This way, we will look polished on
Windows while avoiding the non-native look on other platforms.
Even on windows, the grab bars are themeable and we can't always get it right.
IIRC, the 3.0/3.1 look is supposed to look "less busy" than the R21 look (that
was one of the reasons for changing it). So to keep that spirit would mean
removing that box around the fast view bar and intro bar, remove the dotted
drags, and remove the little x close icon on the intro bar. All these appeared
in a recent RC so they should be easy to back out.
minimally for RC4 we should make the two gripper areas and layout wrt spacing
the same for the fastview and welcome bars.

Bug.WithStack:
I20050527-0900, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11
The minimized intro and the fast view bar both have drag/grab bars on the top/left side of them. These bars are drawn as dotted lines, essentially. However, they are drawn differently. This is particularly noticeable if they are placed next to each other. In this corner hailing from T Dot, wearing the red trunks, I give you.... DEJAN THE DESTROYER!
The the other corner hailing from sunny Ottawa, wearing the blue trunks, I gice you... BOXCAR STEFAN!
Let me introduce the referee for this bout - Michael "The Breeder" Van Meekeren.
This fight will be to 10 rounds, with each round lasting 2 minutes.
GO!
Personally, I would rather use the CoolBar and let it render the handle any way it wonts. I got it close to working but had to back out because CoolBar does not support vertical orientation (there is a feature request against SWT).
I think CoolBar would give us a portable solution becuase its dragger would be native-friendly.
Now, whose idea was that I need to wear these hedious red trunks :-)? They make me look fat. I agree that a native dragger would be better... and synchronizing our algorithm would be the next-best choice.
I based my code on the IntroBar, but changed the appearance slightly to ensure that the margins were symmetrical. We should probably go with whatever looks closest to the coolbar-with-xp-manifest look.
So we can track this, dejans bug for coolbars supporting vertical is Bug 92013.
Since it is not going to happen for 3.1, our options are make both dotted lines the same with the same spacing or go with a separator. Linda was going to propose a common spacing solution, Linda? I could not find a bug logged by you so why not comment here?
I suggest we either 1) stick with the dotted line until 92013 is fixed OR 2) remove the feature and just use a cursor change (as in the curve on the top right for the perspective switching bar) to show this feature. I'm not sure that dragging it around is all that important and while it should be possible most people will probably leave it where it is.
We can do the following:
1) Use the same algorithm to render grab bars so that there is no difference between fast views and Intro
2) Render the grab bars only on Windows. This way, we will look polished on Windows while avoiding the non-native look on other platforms. Even on windows, the grab bars are themeable and we can't always get it right. IIRC, the 3.0/3.1 look is supposed to look "less busy" than the R21 look (that was one of the reasons for changing it). So to keep that spirit would mean removing that box around the fast view bar and intro bar, remove the dotted drags, and remove the little x close icon on the intro bar. All these appeared in a recent RC so they should be easy to back out. minimally for RC4 we should make the two gripper areas and layout wrt spacing the same for the fastview and welcome bars.
to be reviewed June 21 approved for RC4 Will do. Assigning to intro for now because intro launch bar needs to be adjusted. Tweaked intro launch bar grab handle to look like the fast view bar handle. Also swapped the location of the 'close' button relative to the grab handle. Created attachment 23665 patch to workbench
Dejan here is what I was planning for the fastview bar to tighten it up. I will load your code from head to see if they are different still. I would be very surprised if they are. Let me know when you are done so that I can catch up. Created attachment 23667 updated patch Created attachment 23668 the fast view bar in all positions
Dejan please copy this , I'm testing this patch on other platforms now Dejan, please hold off and copying this till tomorrow. I found some issues on other platforms that I need to investigate. Actually now that I have had some sleep and looked at this again. I think we should just leave it as it is now that Intro matches the fast view bar. There is a decent amount of space on the side of the gripper that could be tightened up but this also gives more affordance when trying to grab it and move it and it turns out when the fast view bar is empty and shrinks down to the thin bar it is important to have a few extra pixels on the sides of the gripper.
I amd marking this as FIXED for RC4, thanks Dejan. That was my sentiment too - I was surprised that you wanted to further play with it. You need some margin around the grab bar, otherwise it becomes difficult for mouse-challenged users. Actually you only assigned it - I am marking it fixed now :-).
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20050527-0900, GTK+ 2.6.4, KDE 3.3.2, X.org 6.8.2, Linux 2.6.11
The minimized intro and the fast view bar both have drag/grab bars on the top/left side of them. These bars are drawn as dotted lines, essentially. However, they are drawn differently. This is particularly noticeable if they are placed next to each other. In this corner hailing from T Dot, wearing the red trunks, I give you.... DEJAN THE DESTROYER!
The the other corner hailing from sunny Ottawa, wearing the blue trunks, I gice you... BOXCAR STEFAN!
Let me introduce the referee for this bout - Michael "The Breeder" Van Meekeren.
This fight will be to 10 rounds, with each round lasting 2 minutes.
GO!
Personally, I would rather use the CoolBar and let it render the handle any way it wonts. I got it close to working but had to back out because CoolBar does not support vertical orientation (there is a feature request against SWT).
I think CoolBar would give us a portable solution becuase its dragger would be native-friendly.
Now, whose idea was that I need to wear these hedious red trunks :-)? They make me look fat. I agree that a native dragger would be better... and synchronizing our algorithm would be the next-best choice.
I based my code on the IntroBar, but changed the appearance slightly to ensure that the margins were symmetrical. We should probably go with whatever looks closest to the coolbar-with-xp-manifest look.
So we can track this, dejans bug for coolbars supporting vertical is Bug 92013.
Since it is not going to happen for 3.1, our options are make both dotted lines the same with the same spacing or go with a separator. Linda was going to propose a common spacing solution, Linda? I could not find a bug logged by you so why not comment here?
I suggest we either 1) stick with the dotted line until 92013 is fixed OR 2) remove the feature and just use a cursor change (as in the curve on the top right for the perspective switching bar) to show this feature. I'm not sure that dragging it around is all that important and while it should be possible most people will probably leave it where it is.
We can do the following:
1) Use the same algorithm to render grab bars so that there is no difference between fast views and Intro
2) Render the grab bars only on Windows. This way, we will look polished on Windows while avoiding the non-native look on other platforms. Even on windows, the grab bars are themeable and we can't always get it right. IIRC, the 3.0/3.1 look is supposed to look "less busy" than the R21 look (that was one of the reasons for changing it). So to keep that spirit would mean removing that box around the fast view bar and intro bar, remove the dotted drags, and remove the little x close icon on the intro bar. All these appeared in a recent RC so they should be easy to back out. minimally for RC4 we should make the two gripper areas and layout wrt spacing the same for the fastview and welcome bars.
to be reviewed June 21 approved for RC4 Will do. Assigning to intro for now because intro launch bar needs to be adjusted. Tweaked intro launch bar grab handle to look like the fast view bar handle. Also swapped the location of the 'close' button relative to the grab handle. Created attachment 23665 patch to workbench

Bug.Summery: (3.1M7) Static import code assist shouldn't propose <package>.*;
Bug.WithStack:
With J2SE 5.0 compliance enabled, type the following into a new Java file:
import static java.
Code assist will propose all subpackages of java, each followed by ".*;", which results in a compile-time error if accepted.
Instead, it should propose plain subpackages ("java.lang" instead of "java.lang. *;"). Omission: should do another code assist if a subpackage is selected:
static import java.<code assist>
(selects proposal "java.lang") ->
static import java.lang.<code assist>
Could also show subpackages as "java.lang.". *** Bug 108704 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** +1 for 3.2RC2 Created attachment 39406 Proposed fix Fix released and test added CompletionTest_1_5#test0288() -> test0289()
"java.lang." is proposed instead of "java.lang.*;" when the import is static Verified with I20060427-1600 for RC2.
Bug.WithOutStack:

(selects proposal "java.lang") ->
static import java.lang.<code assist>
Could also show subpackages as "java.lang.". *** Bug 108704 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** +1 for 3.2RC2 Created attachment 39406 Proposed fix Fix released and test added CompletionTest_1_5#test0288() -> test0289()

Bug.Summery: code generator shouldn't override project's build path

Lines.Line: 1) I have generated some code from the model.
2) I create a junit test-case class to test some things with my model. When
creating the test-case class, eclipses adds junit.jar to the project's build path.
3) I find that there is something wrong with my model, so I change it and
regenerate the code.
4) The code generator overrides the project's build path, thus removing
junit.jar from it. Now my test-case class doesn't compile.

Bug.WithStack:
When opening a file.genmodel and clicking "Generate Model Code", the code generator overrides the project's build path, thus destroying other dependencies.
Here is a simple example: 1) I have generated some code from the model. 2) I create a junit test-case class to test some things with my model. When creating the test-case class, eclipses adds junit.jar to the project's build path. 3) I find that there is something wrong with my model, so I change it and regenerate the code. 4) The code generator overrides the project's build path, thus removing junit.jar from it. Now my test-case class doesn't compile.
It frustrates me that I need to add junit.jar everytime, or that I need to have my test classes in another project. I don't see why EMF needs to override the project's build path. To the best of my knowledge, EMF requires some jar files in the project's build path so the project can be deployed as an eclipse plugin. However, this can be achieved by *appending* those jar files to the build path instead of completely overriding it.
Thanks,
Jonathan Johnathan,
EMF generates a plugin specifically for writing JUnits so it seems best to create your JUnit there. In any event, the GenModel also has a property "Update Classpath" that you can set to false to turn off the behavior you don't like.
The newsgroup is a good place to raise issues like this...
Bug.WithOutStack:
When opening a file.genmodel and clicking "Generate Model Code", the code generator overrides the project's build path, thus destroying other dependencies.
Here is a simple example: 1) I have generated some code from the model. 2) I create a junit test-case class to test some things with my model. When creating the test-case class, eclipses adds junit.jar to the project's build path. 3) I find that there is something wrong with my model, so I change it and regenerate the code. 4) The code generator overrides the project's build path, thus removing junit.jar from it. Now my test-case class doesn't compile.
It frustrates me that I need to add junit.jar everytime, or that I need to have my test classes in another project. I don't see why EMF needs to override the project's build path. To the best of my knowledge, EMF requires some jar files in the project's build path so the project can be deployed as an eclipse plugin. However, this can be achieved by *appending* those jar files to the build path instead of completely overriding it.
Thanks,

Bug.Summery: Can't build national fragment with 3.1 M7
Bug.WithStack:
I'm using PDE builder in 3.1 M7 driver to do the headless build of our product. I got error messages saying org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Unable to find plug-in: com.ibm.xxx.xxx.nl1_2.0.0. Please check the error log for more details. The same product was able to be built under M6. Any more details in the .log file? The .log file could not be found in the workspace. So nothing is in Window>Show View>Other>PDE Runtime>Error Log related to this problem? Created attachment 21958 Build log
This is the log generated during the build. I'm sorry that I didn't look for it at the right place. I know nothing about your PDE build configuration but it would appear that either com.ibm.etools.zos.subsystem.uss.nl1_3.0.0 is missing or a dependancy of this plugin is missing.
Nothing has changed in your build except for moving from M6 to M7? This is a quite simple case. There is a feature which contains the plugin and another nl feature which contains the nl fragment. There is no change to the product itself. The only change is moving from m6 to m7. The fragment itself was checked out from cvs in the same build as well as the plugin. The plugin can be built without a problem. Since your scenario is simple, could you please provide us with a reproduceable test case. Note that we don't need any code, the various manifests and the build.properties are sufficient. Created attachment 22087 testcase
Here you are. The attached test case is incomplete. It does not contain all the necessary prerequisites. The same problem should occur in the workspace. It used to build well in m6. Can you please tell me what's missing? Thanks com.ibm.etools.systems.core is the first one that I encountered (required from subsystem.uss), but I also noticed that at leat both systems.universal and com.ibm.etools.zseries.util are also missing. Please make sure that all the appropriate plugins are provided, or even better try to provide a simpler test case. Thx.
com.ibm.etools.zseries.util is in the testcase I sent you. Would you please check it again? com.ibm.etools.systems.core and systems.universal are in the baseLocation. If I skip the language fragment feature, I can build my main feature without problem, which means all the dependencies are there I guess. The example was incomplete, but after bashing multiple plugin.xml I noticed that some of your fragments are incorrect: the plugin say it is 3.0, and the fragment is for 2.1. This a dup of #98593.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 98593 ***

I'm taking it out again, but this might be an issue if people are using Eclipse for weblogic specific development. I don't find a test case to reproduce the bug.

Bug.Summery: Partial patch for jarred bundles not working easily
Bug.WithStack:
As far as I know, a partial patch has to be installed as unpacked. If the original plug-in was not unpacked, was running from a jar, the patch is installed correctly, but does not run. This is because jarred plug-ins with manifest.mf and some code have different classpath, are built differently, and are not simply jarred versions of unjarred plug-ins.
That makes delivering a small patch to a jarred plug-in complicated because it requires more changes to the plug-in and more testing. Konrad, is this something that can be fixed in rc2? you did some work on this earlier. We did not think it will be significant limition, at the time so I have not investigated how much it would take for implementation to add files to existing jar, to allowed jarred partial patch. It is not critical for 3.1, but I think it would be good to fix for RC2. Branko, see if it is something safely doable in a couple of days. This is a mass update of Platform Update bugs that have had no activity in three years. Platform Update was replaced in Eclipse 3.4 (2008) by a new provisioning system called Equinox p2. If this bug or enhancement is not already addressed in p2 please enter a new bug report against p2 (RT > Equinox > p2). If you still want to see this bug addressed in the deprecated Platform Update component, please reopen this bug. Patches welcome.

Bug.Summery: Debugger doesn't highlight source when stepping

Lines.Line: 1. Start Tomcat in Eclipse
2. Set a breakpoint in a Java file that is accessed (e.g. Struts Action class)
3. Access a page that calls the action with the breakpoint.

Bug.WithStack:
Whenever I step through source code in a webapp, the debugger doesn't highlight the code nor does it step to any source files that are outside of the entry point file.
I'm using Tomcat 5.5.9 that is started with the Sysdeo Tomcat plugin. The problem wasn't present until 3.1m6. Created attachment 21915 Shot of the debugger in action with no highlighted source Created attachment 21916 Shot of my debug pointer options to show that text highlighting is turned on Does the problem occurr in 3.1RC1? Problem still occurs in 3.1RC1. Need steps/sample application to reproduce. As well, it would be helpful if you could re-test on RC3. Problem still occurs in 3.1rc4
Steps to reproduce. Note: I'm using the Sysdeo plugin to start Tomcat within Eclipse. This allows me to easily attach to Tomcat for debugging. 1. Start Tomcat in Eclipse 2. Set a breakpoint in a Java file that is accessed (e.g. Struts Action class) 3. Access a page that calls the action with the breakpoint.
Results: the debug view shows the correct line of code being debugged but the file with the breakpoint is not brought into the foreground view. When I switch over the file, the line being debugged is not highlighted. Could be a problem with sysdeo - needs investigation. Does the problem happen when debugging a stand alone Java App? I'm primarily a web developer so I can't as to whether the problem exists with a standalone app. I will write up a small 'hello world' deal soon to test it out. The problem does not exist when I debug a standalone, simple application. Marking as works for me. Sounds like a problem with sysdeo, or perhaps debug attribtues missing from classfiles you are debugging against. This is how I normally fix it when debugging under Sysdeo with Tomcat 4.1.x: a) make sure the project is open; b) stop tomcat; c) go to Window > Preferences > Tomcat > Source Path; d) check the checkbox next to the project; e) save preferences. After this debuging is fine, no idea how and why. Thanks for updating - sounds like a Sysdeo configuration issue.

Bug.Summery: [content assist] Autocompletion failure in foreach loop
remove remaining occurrences of "com.ibm" in code or artifacts
Bug.WithStack:
We need to remove occurences of "com.ibm" in code or artifacts in the XML related components. Many of these are property values. There may be some others that are Rose model related. org.eclipse.wst.dtd.validation.internal.ui.eclipse.DTDValidatePlugin.java contained CONST_XSD_DEFAULT_PREFIX_TEXT and CONST_XSD_LANGUAGE_QUALIFY, both of them had their string value containing "com.ibm...".
Lawrence did a search and found out these two attributes were not referenced anywhere. So they have been removed from the code.
Changes are in dtd.core, wsdl.ui, xsd.ui and xsd.validation in v20050611_0054 version. Verified in lastest HEAD stream.

Bug.Summery: Update sites modifications are permanent even if canceled
Bug.WithStack:
Select: Software Updates -> Find and Install -> Search for new features to install.
Modify anything: include a new site, or edit a existing, or remove.
Select cancel, and return to this dialog again. The modifications were not "canceled".

Bug.Summery: <update> url in feature manifest does not appear as a update site
Bug.WithStack:
3.1 RC1:
According to Eclipse documentation, the <update> element in feature manifest can be used to indicate the update site for this feature.
The list in update dialog does not show this "feature-contributed" type of update site.
However, it shows the site listed in <discovery> element.
It can be observed in the EHEP plugin (http://ehep.sf.net). Its feature.xml uses the 2 types of URLs. only discovery url's are shown in the list. the update url's are for finding updates to the existing features, and never displayed. you can contribute the same url string for both update and discovery url's.
Bug.WithOutStack:
3.1 RC1:
According to Eclipse documentation, the <update> element in feature manifest can be used to indicate the update site for this feature.
The list in update dialog does not show this "feature-contributed" type of update site.
However, it shows the site listed in <discovery> element.
It can be observed in the EHEP plugin (http://ehep.sf.net). Its feature.xml uses the 2 types of URLs. only discovery url's are shown in the list. the update url's are for finding updates to the existing features, and never displayed. you can contribute the same url string for both update and discovery url's.

Bug.Summery: <discovery> element with type="web" should not be used as a update site
Bug.WithStack:
3.1 RC1:
As stated in http://help.eclipse.org/help30/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/misc/feature_manifest.html, in feature.xml, <discovery> urls with type="web" should be treated as a regular site, and should not be treated as a update site.
If you install the EHEP plugin (http://ehep.sf.net), the EHEP Web Site will appear in the update site list. The "web" type is deprecated and no longer supported, but, yes, those urls should not be displayed. And the documentation must be updated... :-) yes, where is the patch? :-) (In reply to comment #1) > The "web" type is deprecated and no longer supported, but, yes, those urls > should not be displayed.
Is this still true? When was this deprecated? Is that deprecation documented somewhere?
In v.3.3.2, build ID M20080221-1800, discovery sites with type="web" still appear in the Update Sites to Visit dialog, and Update Manager looks for a site.xml file at the <discovery url="..."/> specified in the feature.xml file.
Also, the <discovery> element type attribute still appears in the most current Eclipse documentation at:
http://help.eclipse.org/stable/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/reference/misc/feature_manifest.html
Is there someone from p2 team listening to this bug that can verify if this is will be handled correctly in the new update manager? (and be fixed in the documentation :) CC'ing John as he just implemented this support for p2. p2 will ignore discovery sites of type 'web'. I have updated the documentation. This component is obsolete and only major bugs are being fixed, so I'm going to close this.
